38905307.review:
I knew this game by reputation going in, and I assumed that it wouldn't have anything to it besides the curveball it's most known for, but it's a well-crafted puzzle-platformer with functional controls and clever level design. It may be short, but considering how simple it is, I think it's the perfect length for its kind. 

Each eversion level has its own rules of what's solid and what isn't, and you'll have to jump back and forth between 3+ levels per stage to collect all of the gems and reach the end. The final gem stage in particular requires you to put all of your knowledge of what each eversion level entails to good use if you want all of the gems, and it was easily my favorite part of the game for how much it makes you think.

Some of the jumps later on are a pain, especially on the path to the true ending, and I wish the game would be clearer on what to do once you have all of the gems, but those are my only complaints. Well worth your money, even if you're spoiled.

35763733.review: Eversion is simply a 2d platformer where you move from left to right, collect items, defeats enemies, and utilize the "eversion" mechanic to travel between different versions of levels. On the surface, this seems rather simplistic, and it is, but the eversion mechanic is surprisingly in-depth, with each object having different properties in each version of a level. These differing properties allow for a variety of intricate puzzles. The game also excels at teaching its mechanics through shear level design as opposed to a text-based tutorial, something that I'm always happy to see. Through in a great soundtrack and some - er - shocking visuals, and you've got yourself a fun little platformer that I'd definitely recommend.

I've played it through it 100% about three times now but I only have 7 hours logged into it. If you like to get a big bang (playtime) for your buck, look for it even cheaper than the base $5 during holiday sales.

35486936.review: Eversion plays quick and pretends to be innocuous, but don't be lulled by its innocent look: this is one mean puzzle-platformer. The game's seeming simplicity makes the mechanics by which its world works immediately apparent, but the levels become demanding faster than you'd expect. First you'll find yourself working out the logic by which many of the more out-of-reach gems can be collected, but as you gain proficiency with Eversion's particular style of platforming, you'll soon find yourself tested on your ability to execute precise leaps and on your persistence in the face of intense opposition. This game is pretty difficult to master, but play through to the end at least once and you'll see why it's one of the all-time classics.

[list]
    [*]轻松易上手，一个小时就通了（普通结局）
    [*]画风卡通，音乐动听，小孩子也会喜欢
    [*]类似马里奥的“拯救公主”剧情，引人入胜
    [*]创新的玩法
    [*]岚少倾力推荐
[/list]

[spoiler]行了我不瞎编了，这是第一个让我玩的想吐的platformer。
我在别的地方玩过很多跳台游戏，比这难的也接触过一些，然而这游戏的难度和猎奇度混在一起，成功的塑造了一种”令人恶心“的氛围。
游戏猎奇之处是多样化的：不仅有世界一步步转变时，逐渐逼近的绝望感，也有从第一世界直接变成第五世界、悬崖下伸出枯手的jumpscare。
关卡设计我认为相当成功。我的意思是，在恶心人这方面很成功。这游戏的目的大概是让你做噩梦，而不是让你觉得里面的谜题怎么好玩。各方面的恐怖，才是这个游戏最令我着迷的地方。 [/spoiler]
综上所述，本作无愧于”幻之名作“这一称号，推荐给所有[spoiler]对自己睡眠质量有自信的[/spoiler]玩家！

Игра представляет собой вопрощение одной неглупой в общем-то идеи, которая с одной стороны деконструирует жанр платформера, а с другой - служит постмодернистким комментарием к этому жанру. К сожалению, вырвиглазная графика, странный видеорежим и хтоническое пиканье в качестве саундтрека приводят к тому, что у меня лично уже спустя 15 минут игры начала раскалываться голова (при этом что в какой-нибудь Diablo 3 первые признаки физического дискомфорта появляются часов через шесть непрерывной игры). 

Ну и уже спустя 15 минут заметно то, о чём пишут другие отзывы - геймплей рассчитан на беготню туда-сюда, унылый сбор кристаллов и чрезмерное применение той самой неглупой идеи, которая при таком подходе довольно скоро начинает утомлять. 

Если вам нужен действительно стоящий постмодерн, то рекомендую обратить внимание на [url=http://steamcommunity.com/id/alpasy/recommended/405640]Pony Island[/url], [url=http://store.steampowered.com/app/224760/FEZ/]FEZ[/url] и [url=http://store.steampowered.com/app/26800/Braid/]Braid[/url] (из того, что приходит в голову в первую очередь).

34725983.review:
Eversion is a game best suited for diehard platformer lovers who enjoy redoing puzzle aspects over and over again or any player who can brave those aspects to enjoy the effect of the player's actions on the world.  Anyone else should probably watch someone else play this game instead.

The game does not mess around after the third level: if you can't jump at the exact height in the exact arc at the exact time the game wants you to, you're not going to be able to complete the level any time soon.  The game has a checkpoint system and an infinite amount of lives so there's no pentalty for starting over, but it takes a ton of time to memorize the level design and master the timing to pull a lot of the jumps off.  This is a great time if you love challenges and dying a ton, not great if you don't enjoy replaying the same parts of a level 30+ times over.


If you like the idea behind the game but can't spend the 3+ hours it takes to master a level's layout, buy it for your hardcore platformer friend and watch them play it for you.  It's a worthwhile game for those who like hard as balls platformers, but super hard to reccomend to anyone else.

32972006.review:
Eversion is a simple looking and playing indie platformer, just another drop in the flood of "retro" platformers we've seen since Braid. Eversion, like Pony Island, presents itself in a cutesy way but quickly succumbs to a subversive horror element. This is just edgy, needless window dressing -- the creepy stuff neither meshes with the game nor impresses on any level.

What is kinda interesting is that use of "layers." At certain points in a stage, Zee Tee (your avatar in the game) can trigger a "door" to another layer of the level. It feels like a hokey version of the time alterations seen in Sonic CD, but it provides some variety to the otherwise by-the-books platforming. Moving through the layers is too clunky to be truly enjoyable; and the poor enemy design, some collision issues, a poor and repetitive soundtrack, and the game's penchant for shutting down after clearing one of the endings annoy as well.

The real reason to buy Eversion is for its Steam cards. The game's foil badge is the best badge available on Steam, and the cards sell for quite a bit of money. I'd marginally recommend this one with the outlook that the game is more of a consolation prize should you not be fortunate enough to receive a foil card. Eversion is built well enough to hold my interest, but it's a pretty lukewarm recommedation all the same.

32841995.review:
I found this game while looking for ones similar to Pony Island, and I wasn't disappointed.

It's not the most fantastic or longest game ever, but that's fine, because the content that was there was more than enough to satisfy, and I'm happy with the price I paid. That said, I did get it on sale.

The main complaint I see in other reviews is that the platforming can be hard at times. They're not wrong, but I'm the kind of person who develops salt quickly if he loses in an FPS, and I only found it particularly frustrating when lag was involved or I got stuck (there's a couple places where that can still happen). Fortunately, checkpoints exist and are decently spread out so that you won't have to repeat too much, and the main game is still easy enough to not have too many issues with it.

All in all, while I'm not sure five dollars is the best price point, I'd say the game is absolutely worth a look, and if it's on sale, you should definitely pick it up.

32727928.review: Short but interesting puzzle game, not bad for $2-5 and a few hours.  Definitely has a very interesting mechanic that's worth exploring!

32673920.review:
[h1]I really wish there were a "Mixed" recommendation button.[/h1]

Eversion was mechanically interesting. It clearly aspired to parallel the puzzle platformer prowess set by [b]Braid[/b], even to the point of dropping references to it (see the Achievement named "Metaphor for the atomic bomb"). It does however, fall a little short. Granted, Braid is an ambitious benchmark, being - at least for me personally - the greatest puzzle platformer of all time.

Eversion's core mechanic was not immediately obvious, and the emphasis on learning simultaneously with game progression is a design choice I have an affinity for. The music and graphics were both acceptable, neither particularly standing out, but both serving their purposes well enough in [spoiler]applying some initial misdirection[/spoiler].

[url=http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=953106429]The real problem comes in the form of hitboxes.[/url] The character model is designed so that elements stick out unpredictably, making moving through small gaps challenging. 60% of the game is falling and jumping through small gaps. This became frustrating to no end; I've played numerous precision platformers in my time, and yet, due to Eversion's hitboxes, I found myself dying repeatedly on seemingly straightforward sections. It seems like an asinine complaint, but this minor fault had such a considerable effect on the overall [i]game feel[/i] that it degraded the entire experience for me.

TL;DR - Initially enjoyed, but design faults made it more frustrating as I progressed.

[b]5.5/10[/b]

30064070.review:
Ah eversion, my oldest steam review. Or at least second oldest. This game is actually the reason I decided to finally get a steam account, after playing the original a year before. Me and a few friends were talking about this game recently, and I wanted to revisit my review as a lot has changed over 6 years.

Eversion is a sidescroller platformer/puzzle/horror game in which you are a little flower named Zee Tee and your goal is to make it to the end of the game to save the princess.

Woah, did you just spoil the fact that it was a horror game? Yes. But don't worry, the trailer does it for me. And every other joke review. And the title screen that says "Not for children or those with a nervous disposition". But I do think that this game could be important to a few people who are considering playing it, so I will say a short review before I spoil any more:

[h1]Before Spoiler TL;DR[/h1]: Eversion is a game with frustrating platforming, too-tight/perfection needed jump physics, and "where the hell do I go" puzzle elements. The gimmick of the game doesn't save it. However, if you are interested in the concept, you can check out the free version. The HD version has better music and graphics though, along with more endings.

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

I first played eversion when I was browsing vgcats and Scott posted a blog post saying "I don't want to say anything more, just play this game". I think the fact that I was browsing vgcats shows how old I was/my mindset at the time. Anyways, I played it and was absolutely blown away. I loved it, and it was my first foray into horror games as I previously had been too chicken to bother getting into them before then (also I was like, 12).

Now I look back on it with fond memories, but absolutely dislike almost everything about it. I feel like Eversion was [i]extremely[/i] formative in my taste in horror, rather what I [b]don't[/b] like in horror at all now-a-days. I feel like it's really easy to say that it's "edgy" or "tryhard" in it's horror- and while that may be partially true, I feel like those are both subjective terms. Like what is tryhard to you? What does edgy mean to you? So to put it in more objective terms, Eversion has no subtlety at all. It beats you over the head with it's horror like a brick. Every psychological horror game trope is in this game, and it's presented straight-faced rather than a homage or a tribute. You've got the distorted music, jump scare hands flying up from the bottom of the screen, messages saying "BEHIND YOU" and "I SEE YOU", fountains of blood pouring out of enemies as you stomp on them, the list goes on. Hell, to put a cherry on top the game automatically closes after you beat it. While these were all new to me when I was 12 and first experiencing horror games, now it just comes off as tired. It's not even like these were innovations in 2008, you can play many games like Eternal Darkness, Silent Hill, Yume Nikki, and F.E.A.R. years before and get some extremely similar elements in those games.

But ok, I can't with good conscience write a game off completely just because I don't like it's atmosphere. But the horror gimmick of Eversion isn't even the problem with Eversion at all, it's the gameplay. The platforming is too tight, as in there is no leeway for the player at all and the physics are stacked against you. If you try and jump from a block directly below you to one directly above you, you don't slide up the side of the one above you if you're a bit off like in mario. The enemy killboxes are extremely punishing if you are trying to make a huge fast leap on their heads to pass through a section. The hell hands that come up from the ground later in the game come up too slow sometimes, so even if you know where they are you can still get hit by them if you're trying to pass under. Even the graphics get in your way sometimes, like when you jump on an enemy and blood flies out everywhere (which are just giant red spheres) which temporarily can block your vision of where you're landing. This is all accented by horrible level design, which requires you to do all of the above I just mentioned. It actually requires you to do it constantly by the 4th or so level. It wouldn't be so bad if these aspects of the platforming were more forgiving towards the player, but tough luck, they aren't. Also, don't even get me started on the autoscroller advancing wall of death sections. It gets even worse when sperm hands start flying at you.

The puzzle element isn't much better. Initially you can mash the evert button to see where the eversion points are, but after a certain point you have to find them yourself. This results in the frustration of looking all over the map for the one eversion point that will allow you to collect all the gems or beat the level. But this gets easier once you realize that the eversion points are only placed in the most annoying, inconvenient spots possible. This is where the frustrating level design comes in. But on top of that, to get all the gems (required to play the last level and get the true ending) you constantly have to backtrack back and forth through the level multiple times. It's just not fun.

The reason I brought up the horror gimmick is because I feel like if done better this could have been the game's saving grace. The game is well enough made from a graphical and programming perspective, it's the actual game design where it all falls apart immensely. If the game was more tounge in cheek with it's theme and knowing that it's just a silly cute horror game, or more subtle and drawn out with it's scares leading to a more oppressive atmosphere, I could excuse the bad platforming and still call it a good experience regardless. 

All in all, Eversion is kind of like a really bad haunted house that's down your street. It's not scary, is trying REALLY hard to be, and it kind of sucks, but you can't really get mad at it because it tried real hard and put a lot of effort in. I love the graphics of Eversion, and I love the soundtrack when it's not trying to be scary by tempo shifting a previous song or replacing it with just a heartbeat.

Eversion starts with the line "not intended for children or those of a nervous disposition", but that's exactly who I recommend it for. I'm not even saying this as a quick last jab at the game for not being scary, I'm being dead serious. It's a horror game that, if you haven't experienced many horror tropes yet, is a good introduction to them. It's also not that scary if you're new to the horror genre. It's a good first step into what otherwise is a rather inaccessible type of game/movie without getting your pants scared off.

29965937.review:
"Eversion" is defined as the process of turning something inside-out. I'm going to attempt to spoil as little as possible here but I'll say up front that it's a terribly appropriate name, and figuring out why for yourself is one of the little pleasures to be found here. Working out the mechanics and the strangely twisting road to the end is a big part of the appeal, so I'll say this: If you're a fan of things that start pleasant and turn sinister, stop reading here and get eversion for yourself. I very much doubt you'll be disappointed.

There's a princess and she's kidnapped and your little flower dude gotta save her from button-mushroom-looking guys, as if you couldn't tell the Mario pastiche from looking at it. Mister flower here can move and jump, enough to stomp enemies and bump boxes for gems. He can also evert, which changes things in ways I'm not going to expand upon. The challenge appears straight-forward at first but everting means every level has a lot more layers to it than it appears. Add on top of that a few hundred gems to collect if you're up to it and a few well-hidden secrets, and you've got a tight little game to challenge your reasoning and reflexes.

It shouldn't take you more than an hour to beat the game, but the gems let you access an additional level and a different ending. Scoring them all will take some puzzling and that last level builds on what you've done up to that point in a really clever way. There's not much point in me continuing to be vague so trust me when I say eversion is a smart gimmick done right. It's small in scope, challenging in the right ways, and looks the part with its simple, colorful graphics. The secrets and surprises in store for you are well worth taking a chance on this one.



Did you enjoy this review? I certainly hope so, and I certainly hope you'll check out more of them at https://goldplatedgames.com/ or on my [url=http://steamcommunity.com/groups/audish#curation]curation page[/url]!

29070191.review:
Let's get this out of the way right now: I'm not that great at platformers, but I'm very patient. If I do something enough, I'll eventually get it. With that being said, that is exactly how this game went for me. I had to be very patient, because I died A LOT. 

I've owned this game for quite a long time, but just got around to finishing it today and getting 100% acheivements on it. The reason I put it off so long? Couldn't quite get one of the jumps in the 4th world, and subsequently lost interest. This game is very specific, and punishes even the smallest errors once you've made it to world two or three. I would advise against playing this game if you're frustrated easily, or if you think it'll be a walk in the park. That being said, I'm sure there's a lot of people out there better at this kind of thing than me. 

When you get down to it, the game itself is both interesting and boring in different ways. There's no greater message to this game, no huge meaning to it. There's just a basic story to follow that becomes more and more "horrifying" the more you play and read into it. I say that in quotes because I don't find it scary at all. It is at its core, kind of unnerving at best, but never crosses further than that. The different endings you get, as well as the progresssion of the worlds and the achievements in a few cases really do add to the atmosphere of the game, which I can appreciate. Its greatest strength lies in keeping the player interested and invested in going to find out what happens at the end of it, despite the trials it takes to get there. I think in that regard, it had me hooked from beginning to end.

Eversion is a very weird game. It's simple, but refined. It follows a pattern, but punishes even the smallest mistakes. It's a fun platformer, but it doesn't push the envelope much, despite coming out over six years ago. Would I recommend it? Sure. But only to people with a lot of determination. I know for a fact I won't ever touch this game again unless someone pays me to.

27060927.review:
eversion is one of those games where if someone tells you to never judge a game by its first impressions, you REALLY need take their word for it! Granted, the platforming-based gameplay is as consistant as the Lovecraftian [spoiler]undertones-turned-overtones[/spoiler], but once you reach [REDACTED], you'll say your first "WHOOOAAAAAAA, DUDE!" even before reaching one of the three endings to this very game! The soundtrack, in and of itself, sets the mood all the way through while also "helping" you find areas to "dimension-shift" through if you play the game without [manually] muting the sound overall...

However, there are certain levels that feel more like solving a puzzle via very particular, yet percise, platforming sequences which, despite being "easy" once you figure them out, can get a bit annoying if you "really" want to collect all those gems... Also, while it is a minor nitpick on my end personally, obtaining the bottom 4 (technically 5 after [REDACTED]) achievements did take looking at a guide in general...

Overall, if you're looking for a deceptive Lovecraftian/horror game that wears that title as that undershirt you find out about after the "subversive" [yet questionable] foreplay section of the overall experience, then I would not be surprised if you already bought eversion like I have... Otherwise, if you're still on the fence about spending 5 bones on a "short" game, then you can try out the free low-res version before buying this high-def version and realizing that not only are certain gem placements different, but a new level/ending can be obtained... Other than that, I [still] wish the soundtrack was available on Steam...

Overall:
This game loves you. It thinks your insides are cute.

The Good:
Genuinely got my heart pounding in a few places.
An excellent combination of two story archetypes.
Both the gameplay and the theme are well developed.

The Bad:
A few of the mechanics are less obvious than I'd prefer, especially that the deeper eversion points need to be searched for.
The "What have you done?" achievement is stupid. 

The Ugly:
I worry that the super cute presentation might keep some people away. I was expecting a cutesy platform-hell game. Instead, I got a cutesy-platform hell game.

26481358.review:
A game that takes the basic concept of a platformer, and twists it into dimension after dimension till it's a dark and scary place to be.

I'm indifferent about this game... it feels unfinished, like more work could've been made. The concept is intersting, but beyond that doesn't offer much after a few levels, which by the time you've already figured out how it works and what to expect. There's some backtracking you'll be facing later on that it'll start to feel tedious and boring. Also some platforming puzzles that can be solved with different dimentions, whether it's positioning an enemy or access to a platform you coudn't reach or stand on.

There are three different endings, depending how much you explored or thought of a creative solution for the last level. There's also a secret scene if you try to modify the game files.

I would wait for a sale though, as this is about as entertaining as The Stanley Parable in mid to late game... and that was a boring game through and through (and a rip-off for $15 [i]grumble grumble[/i]). It's good and interesting, but only good for one playthrough.

For those of you in the trading card scene, I'd say this game is worth picking up. I will warn you if you're going for the Foil badge, though, since most of the Foil cards cost upwards of $50 while even the "rare" items cost less than $1.

23754912.review:
“恐怖，黑暗，困难，lovecraft”，通过标签可以看出，与游戏介绍中的画面与LOGO截然不同，明眼人一看当然知道它是一个典型的“粉切黑“游戏了。
作为一个一小时通关，两小时全成就的小品级游戏而言，这样独特的风格就已足以吸引玩家购买这款游戏。

游戏的核心玩法是“切换世界”，如同盗梦空间的多层世界一样，通过场景中的“裂缝点”，不断从表层世界进出里层世界，随着每层世界的推进，原先“马里奥”风格的场景也变得越来越诡异和恐怖。通过环境要素在不同层世界所表现的不同物理效果来进行游戏，这就是游戏最大的特色了。
在平面地图中移动“寻找裂缝点“是传统的二维平台游戏的基本玩法，而“多层世界切换”玩法则是相当于添加了另一条维度，使得此游戏变得很立体。

不过从关卡设计上来看，除了最后一关（非隐藏关）需要稍稍动脑子进行世界切换的推理以外，其他关卡就都有点一本道的意思了，而游戏“困难”的标签也来自于大量丧心病狂，一触即死，各种不留情的死亡机关。
平台跳跃的难度肯定是有的，不过也不算太高。个人觉得，游戏既然拥有“世界切换”这样一个有趣的机制，不应该光做成“iwanna“那种病态跳跃难度的风格，完全可以在谜题设计上更花心思，加强推理，手脑并用，会更加好玩一些吧？

另外，在游戏中看到了不少braid的梗，甚至可以说，eversion流程玩法本身就是一个“不虐脑残虐手残”版的braid，相信开发者也是从braid那里获取了不少设计灵感才完成了这样一个有趣的游戏的。

当然，“复刻品“的高度必然是比不过真物的，但eversion的想法和高完成度依然值得肯定，加上酷炫的黑暗系对比风格，是一部令人印象深刻的作品。

[h1]То, что прячется за углом.[/h1]

Если вы не знакомы с творчеством Говарда Лавкрафта и Стивена Кинга. Если вы не знаете кто такой Ктулху и Малиновый Король, эта игра вам покажется странной больше чем полностью.
Игра буквально пропитана атмосферой страха, поддельной безопасностью.

[b]Сюжет[/b]:
Мы играем цветочек Зи-Ти, который должен спасти принцессу Нехему. Если вы на этот моменте не выключили игру, значит вам всё равно что начало дофига смахивает на Марио. Но от Марио, Зи-Ти отличает одна способность: выворот (eversion), с помощью неё мы можем заглядывать глубже в мир. Если на первой стадии цветут цветочки, играет весёлая музыка, на заднем плане красуются горы, парят облака, зайдя глубже легко заметить что музыка меняется в мрачную сторону, горы с облаками лишь декорации. Выворачивая мир ещё сильнее, горы превращаются в каких-то существ, из под воды появляются огромные руки, которые хотят нас убить, музыка напоминает какофонию. Вывернув мир до конца уже нету музыки, лишь учащённое биение сердца, всё кроваво красное. От лиц на горах ничего не осталось, теперь это странная субстанция, милые монстрики отрастили дофига большие зубы и хотят нас слопать. При рестартах всё чаще появляются фразы типо "Сдавайся", "Умри", "Мать", "Вижу тебя" и подобная стрёмота.
И да, в конце мы найдём принцессу, есть 3 концовки, но суть практически одинаковая: [spoiler]тебе пиздeц[/spoiler].

[b]Атмосфера[/b]:
О Господи, эта гнетущая атмосфера, эта музыка, задумка автора. Вон он - психотропный хоррор, замаскированный под детскую игру!

(На самом деле больше говорить об игре нет смысла.)

Это просто супер!
10/10

22998302.review:
Note: This game is not suitable for children or for the faint of heart

So with that note out of the way let's get into the review.

Eversion is a cute platformer that hides a dark secret within it. 

In Eversion we play as this little thing (not really sure what he is), but the game is essentially a Super Mario Bros type of story. You try to save the princess and that's pretty much it, but after the first few stages the game takes a massive detour and goes from cute to straight up terrifying.

The gameplay is pretty much the same stuff like in SMB. You can jump on enemies and break blocks, but the game has a twist. There are Eversion points which turn the world into something more sinister. It also helps you pass through bushes which rot with each eversion. The controls however are kind of rough so it get's quite tough to finish some of the stages.

The art style is great, and really helps build tension which each eversion you enter as the game progressively get's more creepy as the levels go on. 

But the soundtrack is my main gripe with the game. It ruins everything and not to mention the later levels are kinda of tough so the soundtrack get's tiresome.

The game took me 40 minutes to finish, but there are multiple endings to get so that extends the replay value.

Overall I though Eversion was interesting, but not full price interesting. Even though it's cheap, I think waiting for a sale is a better choice.

Pros:
+Creepy atmosphere
+Great Art Style
+Multiple Endings

Cons:
-Terrible soundtrack
-Rough Controls

Final Rating:
7/10

If you liked this review please consider giving it a thumbs up and if you disliked post in the comments on what you disliked about the review.

For more reviews follow Snort's Review curator page [url=http://steamcommunity.com/groups/snortsreviews#curation]here[/url] - follow for regular updates on reviews for other games!

22703554.review:
Just like Undertale, Pony Island and The Stanley Parable, this is one of those games where spoilers really will ruin your experience, so if you like platformers, buy this version (there is a free version which I have not played, but it's apparently not as good) and play it without reading ANYTHING about it.

You have been warned... if you care about actually enjoying the game's storyline, don't read any more of my review.

.


.
.
.

Here are my thoughts on the game. The horror elements are very, very well done, although I might appreciate them more if I were familiar with the works of Lovecraft. The core mechanic is fun to play around with for a while - it starts to lose its appeal eventually, but by that point the game is almost over. The leaderboard feels a bit half-baked - the controls are awkward, and you can't scroll the list - but it gets the job done. It's also one of those games where you think you've just paid for a 2 hour game, but then you realise there's a whole lot more. It is for this reason that I recommend trying to get all the achievements.

22252952.review:
Eversion is a special type of game, it takes a cheery platformer in the style of Mario [spoiler]and makes it more sinister the further you progress.[/spoiler]

Your character, an orange flower named Zee Tee, is sent on a quest to save Princess Nehema, the Princess of the Flower Kingdom. There's a twist to his quest, which comes within his special power; to swap between realities via certain points in the world, this is referred to as "everting". However, the more layers you evert to, the deeper [spoiler]and more disturbing[/spoiler] the environments get. 

The main source of praise from me is the game's concept, it takes something cute and cheery [spoiler]and shows its dark, evil side[/spoiler] which is something I haven't seen before (games like Dreaming Mary or Irisu Syndrome! do not count). 

More praise goes to the artwork, the backgrounds look amazing and the way the environments and enemies [spoiler]change and become more deranged as you go through the layers[/spoiler] is fantastic. 

Unfortunately, Eversion is not without its faults. The main problem is the fact that the game is literally a high definition, priced version of the original freeware game. There's only slight changes in the levels and not much else other than to collect a bunch of letters which don't do much. 

What was excusable with the freeware game is the total opposite here, the game is too short for its rather "high" price (which is around 5.19 dollars not counting sales) and fact that there's nothing new when it comes to the levels which are 90% like the original freeware version ([spoiler]the secret eight level is different from the original freeware version pre-1.7.3[/spoiler]) despite the few changes.

If I were to nitpick, another problem I have with the game (adding on to its short length) is the lack of layers, [spoiler]there are only eight layers in the game, the last one being accessable in the seventh level by collecting all 240 of the gems[/spoiler] which is sort of disappointing on my end. However, this doesn't affect the game as a whole.

Despite these problems, Eversion is still (at least) an enjoyable game which deserves more attention. But the game is honestly just a HD reskin of the original freeware version, I best recommend that you play that version instead. Or wait until the game goes on sale. 

7.5/10

Writing this review is a bummer, because if you're reading this, there's a good chance that Eversion's secret has already been spoiled for you. It had technically been spoiled for me, too, but I only knew that the game was "different." That, despite the cutesy screenshots, there was more to it.

That's definitely true. I don't know if I'd necessarily call Eversion an outstanding game. It is very, very simple; even more simple than the games it is clearly trying to reference. But it's the hook that makes it interesting, and in spite of its simplicity, Eversion works within its mechanics extremely well. If you do end up playing this game, don't just finish it once and then move on -- for as short and as basic as it is, you really need to get a full, 100% clear to truly appreciate it.

And appreciate it I did. What Eversion lacks in complexity, fidelity, and length, it more than makes up for in everything else. It's definitely worth checking out.

21125052.review:
[b]"not suitable for children or those of a nervous disposition" [/b]

Take heed of this screen opener. Do not let the kids near this despite Zee Tee's cuteness and happy flowers on the store page. The simple premise in this short platform puzzler is about our brave adventurer Zee Tee rescuing the lovely Princess. It has easy controls with arrow keys and up or Z for jump which can be configured to your preference and full screen mode.

Now if this was the sum of its parts I would not be recommending this game. It is not really a spoiler to say that this is not the whole story. The strength of this title is drawing on the music and nightmarish imagery to invoke a feeling of disturbing unsettlement and confusion. This is down to the juxtaposition of cute 16 bit style and the more darker images as the game progresses .It does not hold your hand in explaining anything.

Regardless if you are familiar with the source material or not this is ambiguous enough for you to draw your own personal theories.  After playing this you will sit and ask yourself [i]"What did that all mean?"[/i]if you are a more philosophical thinker. Or you might think [i]"Meh".[/i]

This game is tagged as horror, in the sense that this is atmospheric but there are jumpy moments. Replayability is encouraged and I [i] highly recommend [/i]that you collect all the gems to unlock more content and get all the achievements. The puzzle aspect for the most part are not frustrating but there are some tougher levels with spots that are easy to miss and some backtracking.

There is a freeware version of this game but I think you should buy the HD Version on Steam as this  has superior artwork, further options and finally Zaratustra Productions did a great job with this game. In conclusion this game, for better or worse should be experienced. If it is in your library already give it a play one day. If you don't own it is not that expensive or you could wait for a coupon or a sale if you are hesitant.

20548968.review:
EVERSION REVIEW

Type of game: Platformer with light puzzle elements

Controls: Supports keyboard and 360 controller. Other controllers I tried required something like XPadder.

Gameplay: The gimmick behind this game is that your character has to switch between dimensions at "Evert" point in order to complete levels. There are a certain number of collectable gems in each level. All of them must be collected in order to get what appears to be the game's true ending.

Visuals: Very basic visual design, although not to the point of coming off as amateurish.

Sound: Certain dimensions have pleasantly distorted remixes of tracks from earlier dimensions, but overall the music and sound design are also very basic.

20380646.review:
Eversion HD is an updated re-release of Eversion. It's important to note some things before coming in. First of all, this version of Eversion is 16 bit, unlike the original 8 bit version you can download for free on the internet. This version also has some bonus content, and extra unlockables, but; I'll cover them as we go.

Eversion for what it is, is a very short game; it's got 7 stages, and a secret unlockable 8th stage. In order to unlock the 8th stage, you have to collect 240 jewels scattered among the stages. Why are you doing this? Because the main character needs to rescue a princess. Yeah, Eversion's not one for story; and it doesn't need it at all. But it is interesting to note; that Eversion is based off the writings of H.P. Lovecraft.

That of course means, that the game is scary.. But not "Jumpscare in your face" scary like so many games attempt. Eversion is scary because the entire tone of the game is dictated by the signature ability; Eversion. When you use it, the world around you changes; and that's the key gameplay element. There are 8 layers of Eversion that you cycle through as the game progresses, and each layer has it's own rules; so the majority of the game is learning how each layer affects your platforming. Aside from this feature; the game plays as a Mario style collectathon with you gathering 240 jewels.

There are 3 Unlockable endings, and after unlocking the "True" ending, you unlock Time Attack which allows you to race the scoreboard to see who can beat the game the fastest. The Time Attack mode also includes the original Stages 4 and 8, as the HD remake made new versions of those stages to replace the old ones. There's also hidden letters that spell out "EVERSION" for a hidden Achievement for those who like to 100% games.

However, one thing I will warn players of, is Eversion gets hard later on. Now, difficulty in games is a good thing, and a game should gradually get harder; but the issue is, Eversion starts off too easy. The first 3 stages are pushovers, with the only challenging part being figuring out how to collect the jewels in them. Once you hit stage 4 however; the game pulls no punchs from here onward. The rest of the game can be a spiraling rage cycle of pure frustration.

-- The Good --
+ Eversion is a unique gameplay mechanic.
+ The music and atmosphere are terrific.
+ The graphics range from bright and colorful, to grim and terrifying.
+ Based on H.P. Lovecraft
+ Easy to 100%.

-- The Bad --
- Huge Difficulty spike midway through the game.
- Little to no replay value once finished.
- Extremely short. (I got 100% in 2 hours).

20351245.review:
Even though the game is *wtf* levels short, i'm glad i got it. I like the idea behind it, the gameworld is... interesting, and at times moving. It's hard to explain in words just why it's good though. Eversion is more like an ink blot. People are likely to see the game differently. Part of why it's such a curious concept.

It isn't appropriate for children, though not so much for the darker or more disturbing elements but because children would probably find it boring or lame or miss the subtle stuff. But since it looks cutesy, it's appropriate that it carries the warning.

Level design, musc and controls are very good. The difficulty spikes up to rage-inducing in one or two places but the whole game is short enough for that to matter very little. Levels are few but worth exploring and replaying.

It's an unusual rather than shocking little game. It's quite basic at first, but worth playing.
Recommended: -10/10

20003777.review:
I'd like to do a Completionist-style review for this game. Because his reviews are awesome.

Foreword, Eversion is a quick Mario-style platformer and also a Lovecraftian game meaning the game starts out cute and bright, but as you progress through, it gets darker and darker. It also has achievements and trading card content to go with it! Eversion started out as a free online game, then implemented to Steam with HD graphics and new updated features.

THE STORY
Zee Tee, the cute protagonist of the game, looking like an orange star-shaped creature with legs, has to go out in the land and save the princess Nehema. Zee Tee is able to "Everse" to different layers of the world. Which get darker and scarier as he gets lower and lower in the layers. The other entities get dangerous and horrid as he gets lower. The game has three different endings based on what you do in the last few levels.

THE PRESENTATION
The game begins in the top layer, where everything is bright, colorful, and cute, just like the first few levels of a Mario game! There are flowers and blue skies. Once you cross to the first eversion layer, which is right below the top one (Not the one you started at), the first layer shows a lower saturation of visuals, and you can see several things have slowly deteriorated. In fact, if you get down into lower eversion layers, they deteriorate even more and the other creatures get more monstrous. Also blood. It's a rather disturbing game. That's why you should acknowledge the fine print at the start of the game: "not intended for children or those of a nervous disposition".

THE GAMEPLAY
The game has seven levels before the main ending. Each level is short and quick. Use the arrow keys to control your character, and press the Space bar to locate Eversion portals and flip through layers when at one. However in deeper layers, you won't be able to locate them, but you'll know when you're at them when the background partially changes. There are also gems in each level to collect and they are required for a secret eighth level and secret ending for 100%. The best part about the gems is they are ALL persistant meaning they remain collected when you die or quit the level. No need having to collect them again! Of course flipping through eversion layers is crucial for going through most levels and collecting gems. There is also a Time Attack mode after the secret ending and you can run through any level in the shortest about of time. It has worldwide leaderboards. I'm working on some good times now. I'm top 40 in the first level, but that's only the first level. Finally, the game has controller support, so grab your Xbox 360 controller if you have one!

THE FINAL LEVEL (SPOILERS!)
I'll actually talk about not only the seventh level but the secret eighth level also. The seventh level is one of the few that goes through ALL the layers. You start at a deep layer where the background is red with demonic hands in the background, and no music. Collecting all the gems is tricky work as you have to go back and fourth through the level to find the eversion portals. You don't need to shift to any layer to beat the level, but when you do. You see the ending with the princess becoming a MONSTER. Game over, then the game crashes. So if you want a better ending, you must beat the secret level. At the start of the seventh level, there is a gem count. If you get ALL the gems in the game, you're able to shift to the FINAL layer where it's the DARKEST ever, with enemies regenerating over time. Beating the level with the final layer takes you to the eighth, which is the same deal, except you need to solve puzzles, locate portals, and get to the end to get the good ending. It's similar to the endless castles in SMB. You start at the lowest layer, and work your way up to the top layer to the end of the level. Then the secret ending, it was much more screwed up, as not only has the princess became a monster again, but ZEE TEE as well. WHAT A TWIST.

So that was Eversion. It's a quick game that turns cute to HORRIFYING quick. It can really unsettle you if you're not prepared. Yesterday I started playing this game, beaten the game, got all gems, got the secret ending, and got ALL achievements. It's THAT quick. However it's $5 for a game you could play for free, but you have extra features. I suggest buying it when it's on sale. Like I did! To conclude, Eversion is a fun game with a really interesting gameplay mechanic. I find it have a nice replay value with the graphics and everything. If you're not like me, it's a game to mess around with for a short time until you go tired of it, or a game you can play to waste time on. I recommend this game. Awesome concept.

It is a Platform mini-puzzle game!

[h1]Interface/Menu/Settings[/h1]


There is no audio volume or toggle available. You have to go to your speaker settings to reduce the volume of the game.

You can play this in fullscreen or window mode, It's either super small window or super zoomed view.
You can play this game with a xbox controller. No Rumble effect.

The game is based for kids, however the game contains alot of flashing. (Switching the layer screen will cause the flash.) Layer screen is changing the gameplay, Sometimes this is required to complete the level or for obtaining gems. You play as some sort of a Flower. Let me guess you have to rescue the flower princess or a Florist?  The difficulty is based on the "layer screen", some of these layers makes it very easy to move on and others makes it difficult. (Some of the background is able to hurt you while others will let you to pass through them). You will launch higher on an enemy if you time your jump.

The music changes on the current "Layer screen".
It has Retro music, (music could give you a headache after awhile).
It has Retro graphics. 
The game is short but has different endings.
Hidden checkpoints.
Has Level selection with a gem counter. There are 240 gems.
You have unlimited Lives and there is no timer.
Gems will be saved no matter what. So even if you quit/die/restart the gems will not be lost.
Gems are not required to finish the game but they will reveal a secret level for an atlernative ending.

The game reminds me a little bit too much from Mario, The "Goomba" thingy and layout in the first level. It has a Mario Finish flag, Goomba looking enemies. and in ending aswell.. Even some achievements...

The Game Closes itself in the end After you have completed it.  TWICE (like a Crash).

Sometimes it is better to kill yourself after you have obtained some Gems which was required to switch some Layer Screens. Just to save your self some "travel" time (This is mainly useful for the gems that you had to obtain in the beginning of the level and was forced to switch layers"


-----------

I will give this a 6/10

19094760.review:
[h1]ANÁLISE DETALHADA:[/h1]

[h1]Enredo[/h1]

No jogo Eversion você controla Zee Tee, um personagem que parece muito com uma flor ambulante. A sua missão aqui é resgatar a princesa Nehema, recolhendo pedras ao longo do caminho. A semelhança com os jogos do Mario é inegável, inclusive por seu enredo inicial simples. Contudo, as semelhanças em termos de enredo terminam aqui: quando menos se espera, o jogo lhe surpreende. Todos os finais do jogo são surpreendentes e imprevisíveis. Apesar de não existir cute-cenes, a história progride de forma linear e satisfatória. Apesar do final imprevisível, isso não esconde o fato que a premissa do jogo é simples, antiga e já muito batida por outros jogos; sendo que desta forma, é um dos principais pontos negativos do jogo.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]

A jogatina é divertida e prende bastante a ateção. Os estágios são fácies de serem terminados, mas mesmo assim, um certa intimidade com o jogo é necessária. Em alguns poucos momentos, é requerido do jogador um pouco de raciocínio lógico, mas nada muito complicado. Entretanto, o grande diferencial de Eversion, aquilo que torna o jogo único, é "Eversão": durante a sua jogatina existirão pontos onde é possível adentrar numa espécie de dimensão alternativa e cada uma possui suas peculiaridades. Em alguns momentos é necessário adentrar-se em uma dimensão especifica para que se tenha acesso a alguma área de anteriormente não estava disponível.
O jogo em si é bastante fácil e não possui power-ups. Apesar de toda facilidade, em alguns momentos em especifico, o jogo requer alguma habilidade de quem está jogando. O jogo em si é muito curto, e facilmente pode-se terminá-lo em menos de 3 horas.

[h1]Jogabilidade[/h1]

Eversion é um típico jogo de plataforma nos moldes antigos: existe o botão de pulo e outro, que serve para mudar a dimensão (botão de Eversão). A jogabilidade é simples, precisa e rápida, assim como deve ser. Os comandos podem ser configurados em um controlador ou em um teclado. Quem está acostumado com os antigos jogos de plataforma se sentirá em casa ao jogar Eversion, onde mesmo os momentos que exigem a precisão milimétrica são feitos de forma fácil e prazerosa.

[h1]Trilha Sonora[/h1]

A Trilha é ao mesmo tempo fascinante e nostálgica. Todos os acordes são feitos baseados em músicas 8-bits. A música durante uma dimensão é a mesma e pode enjoar um pouco rapidamente, devido principalmente ao padrão 8-bits. Os efeitos sonoros são simples e poderiam ser melhorados, mas nada que atrapalhe a jogatina.

[h1]Gráficos[/h1]

Os gráficos tentam lembrar um pouco os jogos 8-bits. O jogo, primeiramente, não roda em WideScreen, apenas em LetterBox. Assim, se você possui um monitor em Wide, acostume-se as duas barra laterais pretas no decorrer do jogo. Além disso, apesar da melhoria notável nos gráficos, elas poderiam ser muito melhores, principalmente por que o jogo custa um preço razoável e a versão com gráficos mais simples é gratuita!

[h1]Veredito Final[/h1]

Eversion é praticamente um jogo obrigatório para quem curte o jogo plataforma. Apesar do jogo ser bem curto, propicia uma boa diversão durante sua jogatina. O sistema de várias dimensões é algo simples, porém muito inovador.

[b]Nota:[/b] [spoiler]7/10[/spoiler]

A cutesy platformer with an interesting twist. The "evert" button is usable at certain places, and changes certain block's behavior. A cloud becomes a solid platform, a shrub becomes passable, enemies slow down or speed up, things like that.

While it did pick up the pixel-perfect platforming, it fails to provide the level of control exhibited by similar games. The controls are floaty and imperfect, leading to signicant frustration when timing delicate jumps.

I will not spoil what little story there is, and I would recommend not spoiling it for yourself either.

The music, while somewhat good, quickly becomes grating.

3/5  Would recommend.

18423953.review:
[b]Quick Breakdown:[/b] A short platformer that centers itself around using what it calls “eversion,” which changes the state of the world.
[b]Length:[/b] 30-60 minutes
[b]Genre:[/b] Platformer
[b]Score:[/b] 5/10

[b]Full Review:[/b] [i]Eversion[/i] is a fairly simple platformer, you walk left and right, jump across platforms, jump on enemies heads to dispose of them, and collect gems; pretty typical platformer fair. The gimmick for this game is the ability to “evert,” which can only be done at certain points of a level. Everting is activated simply by clicking the key assigned to do so at an evert point. When you evert you change the world around you to an alternate reality. There are 7 different realities in use (plus an 8th hidden one), though most levels only use a small number.

You need to find eversion points to change the world so that you can progress though out the stage, as it will change small things about the world that let you progress. It’s not rocket science figuring out how to use eversion to advance, as it’s all pretty straight forward.

When you begin the game the world starts out very happy and cheery, bright colours and all that. As you descend into the later stages of eversion, the world gradually shifts darker and darker.

The gameplay itself isn’t really anything fancy. In the early levels you’ll notice it draws influence from the original [i]Super Mario Bros.[/i] This is most notable in the first stage, as it bears a striking resemblance in how the beginning of the level looks.

The gems scattered throughout the game for you to collect don’t serve any purpose, except to unlock a secret level at the end of the game. I didn’t take the time to unlock the secret level, and after pulling it up on youtube to have a look at it, I don’t plan to either, as it doesn’t look like it’s worth the time.

So is it worth buying? Eh, only if you want a short little platformer to kill an hour (if that). There’s a free version available on the developer’s (Zaratustra Productions), though the Steam version features some minor graphical and audio updates. It’s normally $5, though it’s really not worth that price, so I’d wait for it to go on sale. I wish I could give this game a neutral rating, as it’s not good enough to really recommend, nor is it bad enough to advise against purchasing. Take your pick based on if it looks interesting to you or not.

17570308.review:
Eversion ist ein Plattformspiel a la Super Mario Bros. Um die Zielflagge zu erreichen, kann man im Spiel an vorgegebenen Punkten die Spielfigur phasenverschieben. Dadurch ändert sich das Umfeld. Z.B. kann man auf einen Baum springen und so Münzen einsammeln, die in einer anderen Phase unerreichbar sind, weil dort der Baum verdorrt ist. Auf der anderen Seite kann man durch den verdorrten Baum laufen, während der normale Baum den Weg versperrt.

Nach 38 Minuten hab ich die Endsequenz gesehen. Und ich spiele selten Plattformspiele...
Das Spiel ist trotzdem ziemlich schwer, gerade das [spoiler]Bonuslevel. Bei dem hab ich das Handtuch geschmissen, weil man da an einer Stelle einen Abschnitt zwei Mal machen muss. Wenn man den beim ersten Mal nicht "richtig" macht, muss man ihn noch zwei Mal machen...und natürlich die Sprünge inklusive. Ich saß dann zudem fest und konnte nirgends sterben, musste also Escape drücken. Und das resettet das ganze Level. Macht nicht wirklich Lust darauf, es nochmals zu probieren[/spoiler]. Viele Sprünge müssen genau getimet werden. 

Die Steuerung ist dabei etwas gewöhnungsbedürftig. Die Spielfigur springt nämlich nicht immer genau dann, wenn man es will. Und die Musik nervt...
Fair ist hingegen, dass man unendlich Leben hat. Im Level selbst gibt es auch einen Speicherpunkt.

Alles in allem ist Eversion ein ziemlich durchschnittlicher Plattformer. Im Internet gibts gratis sicher bessere.
Wer schnell ein paar Achievements machen will, kann sich das Spiel trotzdem zulegen.

[b]Das Spiel ist aber definitiv nichts für kleine Kinder!!![/b]

17498948.review:
Short, fun game. Finished it in one sitting, tempted to go back and get all completionist on it. It's a cute game with a very effective atmosphere. As others have said it's one of those better played than explained situations.

I am recommending this game but I'm reluctant to because of some things that I feel should have been fixable.

<CRITICISM>

First criticism: As far as I could find there was no native controller support. Sure I could Joy2Key it or something and if I were to go back to 100% it I most certainly would do that but if you're going to charge money for a platformer in this day and age you should support at least the bare minimum of controllers.

Second criticism: If you AREN'T going to support controllers (or even if you do really) either make sure your mechanics are really smooth and satisfying or don't rely on cheap tricks like long jumps you have to make with a block above you while enemies loom ready to intercept you. That's just one example and in the greater scheme I'm saying either get creative with how you create challenge or tone it down a bit. This game was surprisingly unforgiving and frustrating and it really took away from the atmosphere after a while.

In a way it felt like it couldn't decide whether it wanted to be a Mario/Super Meat Boy style experience or whether it wanted to be a Braid style experience. I feel like it would have been a better game if it had chosen Puzzles and Atmosphere or Unforgiving Platformer and spent more time polishing whichever one they chose.

</CRITICISM>

With all that said, the game wasn't long enough to get extremely mad at and was cheap enough that that didn't bother me. The atmosphere and scenery made up for the lackluster mechanics and overall it was a great way to spend a bit of time. I do recommend you pick this title up, especially if you catch it on a sale. Happy gaming and stell'bsna n'gha...

17177046.review:
Eversion starts off as a jolly happy platformer where you control Zeetee, a walking flower with adorable eyes. It plays and looks very much like Mario; you bounce around collecting things whilst killing monsters by landing on their heads. Get to the end of the game and rescue the princess. It’s all very basic stuff – or so one would think.

What makes this game unique is that the main character has the ability to manipulate the world around him. When that happens, certain objects in the game change. Clouds solidify, making them safe to walk on. Trees become withered, allowing you to walk through them. Monsters stop moving, plants turn hazardous, rocks turn into rock monsters, and so on and so forth. There are seven different stages of world alteration, and not only does it change the graphics and objects, but also the music soundtrack as well.

As you traverse each level (there are eight in total), you experience… well… let’s just say you experience. Sorry to cut this review rather short, but saying anything else might result in unintentional spoilers.

I’ll round it off by saying this; Eversion is no Spelunky. It’s no Shovel Knight, and it’s certainly no game that will last you several weeks or months. That’s Eversion’s one big drawback; it doesn’t last very long. I’ve played it for two hours, and virtually uncovered everything the game had to offer. 

Having said that, I recommend Eversion to anyone mature, who want to discover something a little out of the ordinary.

Score: 73/100

16406309.review:
This is one of those games that makes me wish Steam had a "Meh" option.
Yes, I've only played it for 45 minutes, but that was enough time for me to get the "regular" ending, along with taking a ten minute bathroom break during play time.  Don't read too much into that.
It's a (mostly) solid platformer, comparable (sort of) to the first Super Mario Bros., except the jumping gets a bit awkward at times.  My level of irritation at some of the level design, though, often ended up outweighing my level of intrigue, which is unfortunate, because it doesn't propel me to find all the collectables.  So, in that respect, as a platformer, it's pretty "meh," maybe on the "no" side of the review spectrum.  Same with sound.  It irritated me.
It's the rest of the game, however, that pushes me to suggest this game with a "yes" review.
Every review of this game that you've probably read that says it's scarier than it looks is (mostly) right.  It's definitely an offputting, nervous game, and, as the developer states, not for those of "nervous disposition" or something.  And he's right.  This game'll make you think twice about playing it at night.  But, all told, I didn't find it THAT bad.  While it did catch me off guard multiple times, I don't think it's the kind of game that's going to give you nightmares.  Unless you're a prepubescent, then it very well might.  
So, it's a short, okay platformer with a twist that's worth seeing (though maybe only on sale, or the free version online, of which I hear there is one).
Oh, and some final notes: the graphics, while being pixelated, are pretty tight and often unsettling, as the game promises, but the gameplay is standard platformer with interspersed segments of dimension shifting, which may have been original in 2010, but is no longer terribly novel.
Let's sum it up: Buy it on sale.  It's worth your time, but maybe not worth a whole five bucks.

15782926.review:
I'm not sure how to review eversion. It's an interesting short game with an inspired premise and fantastic soundtrack, but it's been available free for about five years now, and the Steam version doesn't do enough to warrant a purchase over just playing the free version. It does have achievements and trading cards, both of which are pluses, but the game itself is still just a short novelty, albeit an interesting one. Full 360 controller support is missing, something that really isn't acceptable in a commercial platformer, and while the game has a level editor, it doesn't come packed in with the Steam version for no explicable reason. The only real reason to pick this up is if you played the free version and want to support the developer, which is admittedly why I bought it when a coupon came my way.

I like eversion's style, it appeals to me a lot, and I loved it when I first played it, but I wish that the Steam release had at least gotten some basic additions like another set of levels to play through, full controller support, and having the level editor included, or even better having Steam Workshop support for custom levels. If you're paying for the game, you're going to be disappointed, and if you're paying to support the dev then why are you reading reviews. I like this one too much to thumbs down it, but the paid version does way too little to warrant any enthusiasm.

Also fair warning it's pretty damn hard, especially if you collect all the gems, though given the short length that's kind of a plus in my book.

15195095.review:
Eversion is a game that takes a fairly simple idea and turns it into a great puzzle game that's both frightening and lighthearted at the same time.

A lot of people consider Eversion to be a "short" game, but that's not true. Eversion is the perfect length for a game like this- it doesn't drag itself on with needless repetition; it doesn't bog you down with a bunch of throwaway mechanics you only use once; it doesn't try to make itself overly complicated. 
What Eversion DOES do is use it's game mechanics flawlessly- you'll use every resource on the level to get the full completion, and then you can move to the next level. The level design is great, the art really makes you feel like you're a part of this decaying façade of a world, and the music sets the tone of each "world" perfectly.

This is a perfect game for someone who enjoys horror games, but is tired of the same old jumpscares that startled them last year.

Eversion é um jogo estilo Plataforma similar a Super Mario, o objetivo é até o mesmo, salvar a Princesa do Reino da flor, MAS... Ai que vem seu diferencial.
Você é uma Flor chamada Zee Tee que consegue mudar entre dimensões, mas estas tais "Dimensões" são um tanto quanto... Macabras.
Você começa em um mundo feliz, colorido e saltitante, e conforme muda as dimensões, vai ficar mais maligno, escuro e sem cor, até chegar ao seu limite, que é um Limbo completo, repleto de demônios e escuridão por toda parte.

14861208.review:
Eversion с виду выглядит простой и незатейлевой - эдакая подделка под Супер Марио Брос. Сложно поверить, что основная ее фишка - в криповости!  И это именно крипота, не страх, как в ужастиках, а холодок на коже, чувтсво присутствия чего-то гнетущего, нехорошего. Не зря так хочется побыстрее убраться с нижних слоев-измерений. 

Что не так просто: приходится искать дырки между измерениями. А если хочется собрать все кристальчики, то еще и придется слегка поднапрячь мозги.

Слегка - потому что игра легкая, особенно с геймпадом. Хорошее управление - большой плюс, позволяющий насладиться платформерным геймплеем. Головоломки не выжигают мозги. Вообще, игра во всех отношениях весьма уравновешена. Не пререгибает палку, как делают это многие современные игры ("хардкорность" Duck Tales Remastered до сих пор ничего кроме мата не вызывает).

В общем, мне эта игра запомнится как интересная, приятная, ни разу не разочаровавшая меня платформерная крипота. Конечно, рекомендую всем.

14598167.review:
I bought this game expecting a simple platformer with some sort of Lovecraftian story interwoven between the levels. What I got was a rather advanced platformer with a macabre theme. 

I'm not very good at platformers, so I am not the best judge about their difficulty. But there are some things in this game that make it difficult. In addition to some other techniques, this game requires timed jumping, timed levels, and jumping off of enemies. All of these are well known techniques, but they are still difficult. There are no new mechanics to add difficulty, so it is just the difficulty of basic platforming raised to a rather high level. 

I was also interested in the game because it had the 'Lovecraftian' tag. I was expecting some story between the different levels. There was no story. Instead of being Lovecraftian, I would call it just macabre until possibly the very end. Even then it is more of a reference than it is a story. 

I would only recommend this game if you really need to play a different platformer. 

-no interesting mechanics (There is the eversion mechanism, but it is not new and doesn't introduce much.)
-no story
-difficulty is rather high just to play the game

[h1] Ready!
[spoiler] To die [/spoiler] [/h1] – Надпись при загрузке чекпоинта.
Eversion, начинаясь как красочный и яркий платформер, довольно скоро показывает свою настоящую сущность, мрачную и пугающую. Википедия не зря в жанры хоррор вписала! Основой игрового процесса лежит знакомый по Super Mario Bros. геймплей, но с одной особенностью, которая меняет все – выворот.

При помощи выворота игрок полностью меняет мир, геймплейно это влияет на скорость перемещения врагов и осязаемость платформ, но визуально… С каждым выворотом игра становится всё мрачнее и опаснее, горы приобретают пасти и руки, огромные руки появляются из-под земли и пытаются убить вас, а счетчик очков сходит с ума. Даже надпись при загрузке чекпоинта начинает говорить с тобой! Добавьте к этому правильно подобранную музыку и на выходе получиться невероятно атмосферный платформер.

[b] Свои 99 рублей Eversion полностью отрабатывает и заслуживает самых лестных слов. Даже если у вас нет нужной суммы, то вы вполне можете сыграть в бесплатную версию, какой игра и была изначально. [/b]

[b]PROS: [/b]You can try out the freeware version of this game if you're unsure if you'll like it, which is always great! The graphics are simple and the reveals are subtle. Eversion is very clever at "show, don't tell" and does so in a succinct fashion.

[b]CONS: [/b] Available endings may leave you feeling a little unfulfilled. Difficulty curve spikes near the end, which may be frustrating to some.

[b]WORTH: [/b]This game almost never goes on sale, which is a disappointment since it's old yet has aged pretty well. Has the developer forgot about it? Since it has a freeware alternative and is going on 7 years old, I don't see the point in buying it at a full $5.00, especially since it doesn't have 5 hours of gameplay. (My hours were obtained by completionist + guidemaking play)

[b][u]OVERALL: [/u][/b]Eversion is cute and funny! Platforming fans will find an unforgettable little classic to add to their collection and people unfamiliar with the genre may find reasons to get into it.

14090333.review:
This game was something! In a good way.

Collecting all of the gems is ridiculously difficult; be prepared to die many, many times!

I regret reading almost anything about this game before buying it, but realistically I probably would not have bought it if I wasn't aware that it's not what it seems. It didn't end up being as spooky or disturbing as I was anticipating, especially with the "NOT FOR CHILDREN" disclaimer, but the ability to evert to different worlds was interesting and reminded me of Braid.

I really like how Mario-esque the design and controls were, although I royally screwed myself with being unable to time certain jumps when they were actually quite easy. It was very fluid and fast which helped when you were re-doing levels over and over and over that required you to do several things in succession to progress. The music was excellent and the appearance differences between worlds was very fun.

One thing I'm not a fan of is the length of the game paired with the price. It's only 8 levels long, and there's nothing passed that even when you do get all of the gems. That really disappointed me. I guess I anticipated several maps and worlds like Super Mario. 13833328.review:
Eversion is a short and atmospheric platformer, which can be both cute and horrifying. Depending on how skilled you are with platformers, this game should take 1-2 hours to finish. There are 3 achievable endings, from which 1 of them is tricky to get.

The concept of the game is that you are moving between different layers while you are collectiong gems and finish the stages. The higher the layer count, the more the scenery and the atmosphere decays. Without telling too much beforehand I can ensure you, the cute scenery you see in layer 1, will soon be turned upside down.

The switch between the layers occurs at different points in the stages where you can evert to the next or the previous layer by pressing the eversion key. Every layer gives you a special advantage which you need to collect certain gems or finish the stage. The game can be a bit tricky sometimes, but overall it is neither too easy nor too hard. If you are a platformer maniac, this will probably be really boring for you, though.

The BGM of the game is really nice and is different for each layer. Don't forget to increase the volume, because sound will play an important role with your gameplay experience!

The game comes with a total of 14 achievements and 5 trading cards. I personally think the achievement count is pretty low and there could be more achievements added. It was rather easy to get 13 out of the 14 achievements. The thing which really bothered me was the last achievement. Because I am kind of an impatient person I looked it up and damn, this is something noone would think of.

But overall, I can say that this game is really fun even though it is short. Im not sure if it is worth the full price, so if you are not that much into platformers but still want to give this a shot, I would wait until it is on sale.

13581894.review:
This one's good, but with caveats.

The basic concept is innovative - commercial games generally don't tweak their players this way. Not surprising though considering this was originally freeware.

The main mechanic is both interesting (even if it's not entirely original) and executed well, with the level design making good use of it, and fun twists every so often. The aesthetics follow through on the premise as much as is feasible given the style and budget.

That's the good stuff, and it's good enough for the game to deserve a look, especially considering it's cheap and short.

There are however two problems, and they can be pretty big ones depending on how you approach the game - first, the platforming physics are... less than perfect, with unintuitive hitboxes, relatively low jump precision and limited air control. The issue is exacerbated by the level design, which requires high jump precision in tricky hitbox situations in several places, and the second problem, which is bad checkpointing. The player gets unlimited lives and resumes at checkpoints, which is a good decision, but the checkpoints are relatively sparse, and worse - they are usually placed at the beginnings and middles of levels, not after most difficult parts, which means that you can fail a difficult section due to poor mechanics (at least that's what it feels like) and then have to go back and redo the better part of the level, which is always frustrating.

It's worth noting that this only becomes a real problem if you're trying for the secret endings, all gems, or 100% completion, etc. - a regular playthrough should be fun, moderately challenging and mostly frustration-free for most players, so if you're playing for the experience the game will accommodate you and you'll get plenty out of it.

Definitely worth a look!

It's more challenging, it uses the game mechanics very well, and it becomes a neat mix of Super Mario Bros. and Super Meat Boy.

Don't bother unless you're going to 100% it. Definitely worth it.

13061552.review:
Eversion is a puzzle platformer, but discovering the story and setting are an important part of the game.

What makes this game very enjoyable is that the puzzling and the platforming are fun, but never get in the way of the discovering by keeping you stuck at one part to long:
[list]
[*]There are some tricky platforming parts, but nothing insane. Also, respawns are fast, lives are infinite, and checkpoints are conveniently placed.
[*]The puzzles are easy to figure out. They don't require pen & paper or anything, just a few clever uses of the game mechanics.
[*]The game is quite short, as it should be. When the game mechanics are exhausted, it doesn't grind on, it just wraps it up.
[/list]

The graphics are simple, but do a good job portraying the unique setting. A setting that I will not describe, because it would sound boring, but when you play the game it just works so very well. The same goes for the music: simple, but effective.

I recommend this game to anyone who can enjoy the creativity that went into this game, and isn't completely horrible at platformers.

My total time played:
[list]
[*]after 30 mins - got regular ending
[*]after 2 hours - got true ending (I highly recommend trying to get this!)
[*]after 2.5 hours - got all achievements (I used a guide to get the last two)
[/list]

12815786.review:
Eversion is a simple, basic 2D side scrolling platformer. The only twist being that you have the ability to shift environments (eversions). You can shift from six different eversions: deception, erosion, desolation, apprehension, confusion and commotion. Every shift will change colors and backgrounds. The shifts will also turn bushes from leafy, to dead so you can pass through them and into deadly thorn bushes. Some enemies into stone and brick platforms into crumbling blocks. You cannot just shift on a whim, you need to find the invisible area you're supposed to stand in and then shift eversions. When you press the eversion button, if you're close enough to the correct invisible spot, you'll see a ring around it for a brief time. If you're stuck, that usually means you need to backtrack and find the invisible spot.

The gameplay is simple. Like Mario you can destroy bricks by jumping into them and make a gem appear out of blocks by jumping into special ones. Eventually, you will get to see this magical kingdom for what it is. Horrifying, dark and grim. At some point, enemies will spurt bright red blood partially obscuring the screen. Although some might boast this as a horror game, there's nothing really horrific. I was too busy laughing at the giant hands that comically shoot up from death pits. Its too bright and simple of an art style to really be horrific.

There are no power ups. Every hit is instant death, but that's okay because there are no lives. You just respawn at the start of the level or the last checkpoint. The game boasts 8 worlds, but really these worlds are just 8 levels. A world to me feels like it should be more than a level. I was able to breeze through the game in half an hour and that's even looking for invisible eversion points. At the end of each level you hop on a ground flag. There are no bosses, in fact there really only seems to be three enemy types in the game. Monkey claw, goomba and some sort of stone beetle.

Upon completing the game, it just crashed back to the desktop. The only replay value is going back to collect all 240 gems to get better endings that reference better properties. Once you get a gem, it the game considers collected, even if you die on the same run, that gem will not be there. Not having any consequence of death makes things way too easy. This is a quick diversion without any challenge. The forum is full of people giving away 66% off coupons and others talking about how the game is free.

12419519.review:
Eversion is difficult to review without spoiling it, but I'll try.

Eversion is, at it's core, an indie platformer/puzzle game. You play as Zee-Tee the Astrik (*), who is on a quest to save Princess Nehema, who has been captured by things that look a lot like Goombas. Along the way, Zee-Tee can evert to different "layers" of the world by pressing SPACE in certain areas, Things are quite different in each eversion layer, so everting is often required to progress.

Along the way, Zee-Tee can challenge himself by trying to collect all 240 gems, which will often require backtracking at certain eversion layers. Thankfully, your gems save even if you quit the level or die within, which is great for some of the harder levels.

The only real complaint I have about this game is how short it is. The game can easily be 100%ed in an hour, but if it is your first time playing, it'll probably take 2 hours or so to collect all of the gems and rescue the Princess.

All in all, Eversion is a very interesting platformer that is worth taking a look at. If you want to try the game out before you spend 5 dollars on it, the creator has a freeware version on his website. It doesn't have achievements and it's missing a handful of time attack levels, but it should get you used to the game.
