Bought this because I had a 66% off coupon and I don't think I'd pay any more than that. There's a free version of this on the internet which I would recommend instead.

I hope the developers take this idea much further with a new, longer game. I enjoy it but at the moment it's just not substantial enough

PS: In case you didn't know, this game is not what it seems

12380450.review:
«Sounds — possibly musical — 
heard in the night from other 
worlds or realms of being».
– H.P.Lovecraft

Когда смотришь на картинку и слышишь весёлую музыку из главного меню, трудно поверить, что эту игру не рекомендуют детям и людям со слабой психикой. Нет, дело не в потенциальной эпилепсии из-за вырвиглазной палитры. Просто яркие цвета, жизнерадостная музыка, милые улыбающиеся противники… Всё это ложь. 

«Eversion» - платформер с тёмным секретом. Как ни странно, он создавался для конкурса по творчеству Лавкрафта, недаром рядом с предупреждением стоит его цитата о звуках, которая и вдохновила автора игры. Потом автор усовершенствовал графику и стал продавать игру в Стиме, но старая пиксельная версия всё ещё доступна для бесплатного скачивания на его сайте.

Главный герой Зи Ти, похожий на цветочек, должен вернуть похищенную принцессу, по пути собирая кристаллы. Схожесть с «Марио» поначалу зашкаливает: даже первый уровень построен по подобию начального уровня из упомянутого платформера на NES. Это сделано для отвода глаз, и поиск сходств со всем ранее виденным теряет смысл, когда оказывается, что Зи Ти умеет выворачивать мир, оказываясь в его альтернативном варианте. Это можно сделать только в определённых местах, где фон становится чуть темнее и слышится музыка из соседнего мира. 

Но при переходе на другой уровень мира меняются не только два этих показателя: всё вокруг обретает другие свойства. Облака, бывшие фоном, становятся осязаемыми, кусты засыхают и перестают быть препятствием, а потом и вовсе превращаются в смертельно опасные колючки, а кирпичи приобретают всё большую хрупкость: на определённом уровне вывернутого мира их не то что можно головой пробить, а даже сверху ходить опасно, потому что они мгновенно рассыпаются под ногами. Таким образом игра превращается в головоломку, а миры становятся всё мрачнее. 

Перемещение между уровнями одного и того же мира снимает слой за слоем с фона. Изначально это идеально гладкие горы и силуэты далёких облаков. На втором уровне мира оказывается, что облака подвешены на верёвочках, а горы будто состоят из листов железа, соединённых друг с другом шурупами. На третьем уровне некоторые верёвочки рвутся, и обкусанные облака висят как попало, а в горах образуются дыры. Далее эти дыры становятся подозрительно похожи на пасти, а в некоторых местах локаций появляются странные камни, которые вовсе ими не являются… Один из уровней придётся пройти под гулкое биение сердца, убегая от преследующей красной субстанции. Всего уровней вывернутого мира там восемь, так что можно приблизительно представить, до какой степени сгущаются краски. Заметив очередную точку «выворота», постепенно начинаешь испытывать страх: неизвестно, какие ещё сюрпризы ожидают на той стороне.

Концовок в игре три. Первую получите в любом случае после прохождения игры. Вторую, истинную, нужно заслужить: собрать все 240 кристаллов, о важности которых нигде нет и речи, и пройти мозговыносящий восьмой уровень. Третья концовка – секретная.

Если вы взрослый с нормальной психикой, обязательно попробуйте. «Eversion» совершенно не такая, какой кажется на первый взгляд.

The f#ck have I just played?!

A friend gave me this game a long time ago, and asked me to review it. I'm gonna do a longer review on a video later on, but I feel like it deserves a review on Steam as well.

So, what is Eversion?

It's a platorm game, a bit similar in the basic mechanics as the classic Super Mario: Running arround to finish a level while destroying blocks to get [strike] coins[/strike] gems, while jumping arround on enemies....With a twist. In some places, you can change how the world works. In every stage up until the 7º one, there's a new kind of world. And here is where things get messed up.

You see, the first worls are happy as f#ck. Even the enemies you're annihilating smile! And then...Well, things get dark. I won't say more, I don't want to spoil you the fun. All I will say, is that I wasn't expecting such a happy game to turn like that.

The soundtrack and graphics of the game are quite good, it feels like I'm playing a good NES game (seriously, that console had a TON of shitty games), the controls are fluid (I used a keyboard, I don't know if using a controller is better or not), And even though there's not much story, what there is, is...Well, you'll see.

The best part about this, is that you can download the free version of the game, if you want, instead of playing the steam one and supporting the devs. Of course, playing the Free version makes you an #sshole, SPECIALLY WHEN THE GAME IS THIS CHEAP, but hey, there's all kinds of people out there.

Just be aware: You might need to have some balls to finish the game. It has some difficulty spikes, and some parts can be a bit disturbing, to say the least.

Oh, and the video review might take a while. It will be on Spanish, though.

Just remember, the Princess is in another castle.

12172012.review:
全成就了过来写个评测

当初买这游戏完全是因为看了岚少的视频而且朋友正好有优惠券。
游戏操作感不错，整体难度不难，关卡设计也是极为有趣。
渐渐崩坏的世界是这个游戏的亮点，第一关也许你感觉不到什么，但越往后这个世界越来越猎奇，直到......
游戏的成就也是十分好看，一堆眼睛摆在成就展柜透露出一股浓浓的精神污染，故强烈建议此游戏全成就。

-+-+-+-剧透预警-+-+-+-

不收集齐宝石通关的结局是黑化的公主走向我们的小花，然后游戏就关闭了。此时达成了一个成就“公主不在这座城堡里”，那么公主在哪里呢？小花又怎么样了呢？

收集齐宝石之后小花就可以进入世界8了。这是一个完全黑化的世界，怪物是不会死的，而小花仍然坚持去找公主。世界8通过之后，小花便进入了最后一个关卡，这关操作或者眼神不好的就只能一直循环了(这关的创意应该就是来自超级马里奥)。到了最后，快要碰到旗帜时，一只手突然伸出来，可喜的是小花没被抓到。小花若无其事地走向了旗帜，若无其事地跳下了水......
结局时小花也成了怪物，与黑化的公主相爱了，从此“过上了幸福的生活”♥♥♥♥♥(此时游戏开始背景变为第一结局公主黑化时出现的背景)

那么接下来就是第三个结局了，在关卡7用世界4通关就可以达成(前提是达成第一结局）。这个结局中我们的小花又一次见到了公主，但是世界突然就从世界1变为了世界4，小花和公主像被石化了一样，一动不动，留给我们的只有奇怪的背景以及诡异的BGM......

好，说完了结局，那么接下来就来说说看我个人对剧情的理解。

其实每一个结局中小花遇见的都是真正的公主，而导致结局的不同的直接原因是小花自己。(这里要说一下我的判断依据，世界1叫做表象，世界8叫做真实，从砖块的颜色来看，黑化公主所在的世界应为真实，而从画风来看，小花是表象的居民）

结局一中小花还是一开始那个小花，但是它自己的天真导致了自己的毁灭，他选择将自己伪装得光鲜亮丽故没能与公主走到一起。(我对于成就名的解释：小花认为这不是真正的公主，真正的公主应该是和它一样光鲜亮丽的，而玩家也是这么认为的，于是就有了这个以超级马里奥经典台词为名的成就。但实际上游戏从来没说过公主是长什么样的）

结局二中小花选择抛弃自己的伪装，而公主也丢掉了伪装，于是他们走到了一起，从此过上了幸福的生活。(Happy end!)

结局三中小花在经历了如此之多恐怖的东西后，最终发了疯，它认为这么多的东西全都是由于公主造成的，只要将公主永远地困住，世界就会永远光鲜亮丽了。于是在小花见到公主时，它将世界转变为了荒芜(世界4的名称)，将自己与公主固定在了那个世界......(这个结局的成就叫做棕色警报，并且在荒芜这个世界里怪物也是棕色的，而且不能移动。小花与公主被固定住的原因也许是和怪物一样的，它们的本体会由于世界的不同而遭到不同的削弱，只有在真实中才能变为世界的霸主。)

据说还有BUG结局，在BUG世界什么都能杀死你，并且最后的结局是公主在一片虚无中走向小花，走得很慢，几乎不可能走到小花旁边。我在看完岚少的视频时很想看正常的公主和正常的小花走到一起，但在自己玩完这款游戏之后，突然又觉得我想见到的结局真是蠢。但在写完这篇评测之后，我觉得这美好的结局也是十分有意思的，各人有各人不同的喜好吧，我还是挺希望作者能再添加一个这样的结局的。

哎呀，花了一个小时写这篇评测，我还是第一次认认真真地评测一款游戏呢，还不点个赞？

12090518.review:
Eversion Review

I'll try and fairly state what I can without spoiling too much, although if you simply watch the trailer you already know what's going on here.  Eversion is at its core a puzzle platformer, and a clever one too.  You control the flower-faced hero named Zee Tee and rescue the princess, so if you've played any NES game before you already know what to do.

Gameplay is basically platforming but with a dimension-warping mechanic where you jump through alternate worlds.  You may have to change something in one world in order to affect the other world and then you can get to where you couldn't before.  It sounds hard at first but with a bit of practice you will eventually understand what to do.  There are collectables throughout the stages to give some replay value, though I wasn't too interested.  Things do get shaken up later with different enemies and slightly different ways to play the stage, though generally things remains the same throughout.  Of course, the other dimensions might just maybe chinge things up a bit.  I will warn you, it will get stressful.

All I can say is don't watch videos of it or look up other reviews because the main thing here which I didn't discuss will be totally spoiled.  Simply play Eversion and experience it for yourself.

11320193.review:
Yet another entry on the plethora of cutesy retro styled indie platformers, at least, that’ll be your first impression. Eversion was made for an H.P. Lovecraft-themed game competition and it becomes very apparent after a level or two, in which the inane becomes unnerving, and the unnerving becomes insane. This is achieved by having the player character shift through different parallel dimensions in each level, changing the scenery, enemies and making objects in the environment warp into walkable platforms or deadly hazards.

All these elements collide and you’re left scrambling around each level, slowly plunging into the deeper layers, trying to keep your cool while you solve the puzzles so you can collect every last gem and unlock the final level.

The game is of a rather short length, since its gimmick is just that, a gimmick. After travelling through the different layers and seeing how the world transforms you’ve seen all the game has to offer. Fortunately, Eversion is aware of this and will not overstay its welcome, unless you feel like editing levels or playing the time attack mode.

If you’re on the fence, I strongly recommend checking out the free version from the author’s website. The graphics are simpler and the resolution is halved, allowing the player to fill in the gaps with his imagination, making the experience more intense. And if you enjoy it and feel like doubling on the graphics quality, support the author and getting slightly more content, purchase the Steam edition.

11160319.review:
June 4, 2015

I had been working through my backlog, and feeling better in my twitch skills, so I decided to work on beating Eversion completely. I have learned a bit more about the game, and will requalify my review.

Honestly, I was wrong to think this game was hard. It's actually not challenging, just inconsistent in executing jumps at least on keyboard. Disabling the Steam Overlay helps to reduce input lag, but the game is still not tight like Super Meat Boy. Movement is fast and slippery, which makes precision more cumbersome, but it can be done. The gameplay is really basic, simple platforming with minor dimensional differences.

I feel the big problem is that the game does little unique. In truth, you are paying for a minor graphical update, since the game is free online at lower graphical fidelity. For the price, this graphics package is quite underwhelming. There are several palette swaps, but the animations are only a few frames. Music is repetitive, and starts over every time you die. It all feels cheaply put together, more rusty than retro.

The game is short, dimension shifting is more for the brooding plot than for gameplay, and the ending could be reached in a few minutes. As for the plot, despite "inspiration" from Lovecraft and any kind of written material, the plot is laughable. I understand platformers are not known for story, but Braid and VVVVVV did a heck of a lot more in story along with gameplay. For a game that sells itself on "the twist", that twist just made me think that someone needs to stop playing in MS Paint. It feels antiquated, and reminds me of the shoddy romhack creepypasta stuff of Mario online. Those elements probably had a larger influence on this game than Lovecraft ever did.

So the story, gameplay, and graphics are all mediocre, doing little new. VVVVVV just seems to do everything better. Saira is a great puzzle-platformer option with probably 3 times the content, better graphics and music, and is fully free forever on Steam right now. Eversion fails to impress anymore, and feels more like a joke. The developer never bothered to capitalize letters in the few announcements made for the game, so maybe the whole thing really is a joke. Still, not worth the price, as the game never goes on sale anymore.

11128514.review:
I have no idea how describe Eversion. Lets just start with the basics shall we? Its art style is overly colorful to say the least. Its music is throbbingly annoying and will be engrained in your mind forever (think the music of pokemon), especially the song that plays on the first level. The gameplay is frustrating to say the least and is not "fluid" or "tight" as some might say. Honestly, the only person who can say that the platforming is good should be the people who have never played a platformer before (the original super mario bros. was programed more tightly), and even then thats a STRETCH. 

Despite all of this I can say without a doubt, I have never been this afraid of a game before. Not whats in the game, the game itself. The unknown entity haunting the game. If you have ever heard the creepy pasta "BEN is dead" (http://creepypasta.wikia.com/wiki/BEN_Drowned), playing this game gives you the same tingling down your spine as the game begins to try to get in your head. 

If you enjoy a good psychological scare that makes you want to shut off your computer, play this at night in the dark... your welcome.

Eversion ist die aufpolierte Variante eines kleinen, kostenlos verfügbaren Indie-Spiels, was (bis auf die Musik) von einer Person entwickelt wurde.

Das Spiel an sich besticht durch seinen (vorerst) knuffigen Retro-Look, der zwar leider nur in einem Fenster (640x480) oder gestrecktem Vollbild zu betrachten ist, aber das ist für dieses Titel auch völlig ausreichend. Die Musik allerdings ist ohne Abstriche zu genießen und richtig gut!

Spielerisch ist Eversion ein vergleichsweise einfacher Plattformer mit gewissen Puzzle-Elementen, die den Spieler dazu bringen, nachdenken zu müssen und ist trotz ganz leichtem Frustfaktor nie unfair. Trotz verschiedener Enden gibt es aber nur insgesamt acht Welten, wobei die ersten paar Welten relativ schnell durchgespielt sind und das Spiel insgesamt auch leider viel zu früh endet.

Die Story des Spiels lässt sich gut mit der Beschreibung hier bei Steam zusammenfassen. Der dort beschriebene "Mehrspielermodus" und die Leaderboards existieren allerdings nicht, sodass es ein reiner Einzelspielertitel mit geringem Wiederspielwert bleibt.

Dennoch ist das Spiel so liebevoll gestaltet, dass es sich lohnt, ein paar € für ein bis zwei Stündchen zu investieren. Wer das nicht möchte, kann immer noch die kostenlose Variante beim Entwickler herunterladen: http://zarat.us/tra/eversion/#more-173

10383286.review:
Let me get straight to the point first: This is not a terrible game. Maybe not even bad. In my opinion, it is just not worth the money.

Eversion is an Indie platformer which makes me scratch my head when comparing it to the original Super Mario, but only with a flower as protagonist. Of course, this game is a stand alone title, so it has some mechanics on it's own. The most recognizable one is Dimension Shifting. Like it says, you switch between different dimensions which gives the same level a different layout and enemies. With each layer, the level gets more difficult.

Don't get scared though, as this game is hilariously easy. You don't have any lives, so if you were to fall in a bottomless pit or get hit by an enemy, you start at a certain checkpoint. You could compare it to Rayman Origins, but simplified. Besides, it only took me 2 hours to get all achievements, endings and collectables. And I even took my time. But this is of course personal preference as some people prefer short games, which I can clearly understand.

Dimension Shifting itself is a fun mechanic at first, but it gets boring really fast. And that's a shame because it is the main gimmick of the game. If you're interested in puzzles, you might see some light here.

The game only has 8 worlds, which can be completed in a laughably short time. Well, most of them anyways. By doing that you will miss all the collectibles but it still shouldn't be ignored.

The story is ignorable, the music forgetable and the graphics are, while fitting this game, just average. Remember, this is not a bad game but it's just not worth the money. If you are however able to get it on sale or in any other way, give it a go! You might see something in this game I don't.

Eversion is a 2D side scrolling indie platformer where you play as a Zee Tee, a walking flower, who must save the princess of the Flower Kingdom from the evil Ghulibas, at the start the game is cheery and bright, but if you caught from starting up the game the H.P. Lovecraft quote, the game soon becomes much darker.

The core mechanic of Eversion is your ability to swap between layers, or words, and the deeper you go the stranger and darker the the world around you becomes, the actual gameplay is fairly simple and though it does get challenging later on, it never gets to Super Meat Boy levels of frustration.

To give a bit of insight this game has eight levels, you can get every ending and achievement in this game in about two hours, however despite what little there is here, it has charm to it, with the unsettling level and enemy design and tight controls it is fun for how long it lasts, after you complete the game a Time Attack mode opens as well, giving you a bit more replay value.

Note that Eversion is free to download on the creators website, the version you pay for here has more detailed artwork and the aforementioned Time Attack, if you are interested in the game and want to check it out I encourage you to try the free version, but either way this game is well worth paying for, even just to show friends and watch them freak out as the game grows darker.

9752581.review:
"The Princess of the Flower Kingdom has vanished! She was taken by the Ghulibas of the north, and it is up to brave Zee Tee to rescue her."

Yet another spin-off of the classic Super Mario Bros., except maybe a more simple, CreepyPasta twist. You play as a little flower character, Zee Tee. You make your way through levels consisting of a set of parallel realities featuring different hazards and soundtracks to match the atmosphere. Eversion is only possible within certain points within each level. Very sharp and simple controls, easy gameplay (difficulty does gradually increase). Not really any story to the game, but you will definitely have a confused look on your face and most likely be on edge of your seat as you discover what each stage of Eversion really is. Although I found myself really enjoying the game (ignoring the fact I had an upset, confused look on my face the entire time), I dont think $4.99 is worth the price; though I was lucky to get a coupon discount for this game. I beat the game in less than 30 minutes with nearly every achievement earned. But after completing the game, there is absolutely no replay value left, as you have literally just made it through the whole game. But let it be noted, there is a secret ending to work for.

+ Deranged illustration change of each stage of Eversion, keeps you interested wanting to adventure further. You dont know what to expect next.
+ Sharp, simple controls
+ Simple achievements and trading cards

- Price not worth what you get
- Very short game featuring only 8 levels, can be beaten in less than 10-15 minutes if rushed
- Absolutely no replay value, other than working for last achievements (if you're interested at that point)
- No story (not exactly a flaw to me, but may be to others)

I definitely do recommend this game, only for the random and unpredictable twists. Entertainment value increases when playing at night. I would love to see reactions from other players when they start getting into the Eversion; but for $4.99, the price is not worth it. Unless you're willing to drop a quick five bucks, I would say to only get the game if you have a discount coupon.

9741974.review:
eversion - 2D платформер, с ретро картинкой. 

На первых минутах игры, был сильно удивлён сходством игры с Марио, как внешне, так и геймплейно. Похожие враги, такие же способы их убийства, то есть прыгать на них. Сбор предметов путём их выбивания из блоков. А первый уровень, был чуть ли, не скопирован с легендарного платформера прошлого столетия. Однако игра всё же нашла, чем меня заинтересовать. И это в первую очередь, возможность изменения миров. После чего изменяется весь уровень. Нет, не в плане структуры карты, а в плане свойств врагов, предметов различных растений, облаков и т.д. Причём, таких вот режимов более чем достаточно. Практически на каждом уровне, появляется возможность использования нового мира. Впрочем, менять их можно лишь в определенных участках, и при определённых условиях. Такие места практически не заметны, однако находясь в зоне их действия, немного изменяется освещение. Такие моменты не стоит упускать и со временем привыкаешь ловить ту небольшую разницу. Так же при изменении мира, меняется и картинка, тона, цвета и музыка, для различия режимов и удобного их распознавания.

В игре лишь 9 уровней, однако последние довольно трудные и имеют достаточно много миров. Часто приходится возвращатся в начало уровня, после переключения мира, для исследования новых появившихся путей. Самые последние уровни сложные и выход не всегда очевиден, из-за большого кол-ва возможных вариантов развития путей. Помимо уровней на логику,  есть и несколько уровней на ограниченное время, где приходится быстро реагировать, по быстрому пробегая уровень.

9618791.review:
A fun little gem that I seem to keep returning to even though I've pretty much found everything there is to find.  "Eversion" starts out as a bright, cheerful little adventure wherein a little hopping flower guy is seeking to rescue his princess.  But very quickly, things start to go wrong.  Horribly, nightmarishly, wonderfully wrong.  <3

I don't want to spoil too much for anyone who DOESN'T know what they're in for, but this game DOES open with a quote from H. P. Lovecraft for a reason.  You're not going to see Cthulhu and company show up in the world of "Eversion," but you will get that same sense of a normal reality concealing an entire dimension of gibbering madness just beneath the surface, waiting for the unwary person who delves too deeply.  Not bad for a little flower with only two moves (jump and "evert").  

Will it scare you?  Maybe.  It didn't scare me, but then not a lot of games do.  It DID appeal to my particular sense of warped aesthetics, though, so if that makes it sound like your cup of tea, then by all means, give it a go.  You could also find the original free version online if you're not sure.  Of course it won't be in HD, the gameplay will be harder, and there won't be any achievements.  And we wouldn't want any of that, right?

9605814.review:
Eversion is a game unlike anything I've ever played, it's the kind of game that lures you in with cutsie graphics and sweet music, in other words a Super Mario Bros. clone. But this game is far more than a clone. I also highly advise you take the warning on the title screen seriously.

The story of Eversion starts off very simple with the save-the-princess trope, our little flower hero Zee Tee is tasked with the job of rummaging through the lands to reunite with the Princess. Along the way you'll fight goomba-like enemies that are barely threatening. The main selling point of this game is the Eversion feature, in each level there are points where the background changes along with the music slightly, if you press the evert button in these areas the stage will evert, this changes objects in the stages. For example, if you evert in one stage you can walk on the clouds. This makes way for very creative puzzles that test your platforming skills. But this isn't the main reason the game is infamous, as you evert the stages they start to degenerate, I don't want to ruin the experience but as you start to evert the layers in the later levels you'll realize this game has combined 3 genres. Platforming, puzzle, and horror. As far as music goes, the game has some very delightful chip-tune tracks, which then slowly start to change as you evert. The last track is just a plain heartbeat. 

All in all, the game has little over 1 hour of playtime, it's a fun time waster with VERY good plot twists indeed. I'd suggest playing it at night with a friend who has no idea what the game's about.

9508500.review:
Have you ever read one of those "Haunted game" Creepypastas, that really left a sense of fear and dread in your throat, yet you wanted more? 

Yeah... this is the equivilent of one of those.

The gams starts almost cringingly generic, with a bright and cheerful artstyle that looks like one of those bad Mario mobile game clones.

Oh how you will wish you stayed with that happy cute-sy world.
In short, you "evert" between worlds when you pass certain spots in the level. These spots take you to one-off your current world (world 1 you can evert to world 2, world 4 can evert to 3 and 5, etc.). These worlds have different rules, such as scenic clouds becoming platforms and trees becoming dead shrubs. The real notable difference though is the environment. Each world is like a literal decent into hell, and each new world you enter will make you wish you were back in the last. 

The game as a whole is very short, but has such an impact that you will remember this game more than any other game you'll play in a long time.

Eversion is a simple platformer with a really happy and charming aesthetic, as the game's banner may imply. The gameplay is akin to the classic Super Mario games, and while it's mostly straightforward, the "eversion" game mechanic allows you to change the environment slightly at certain points in each level, which gives each stage more depth as it allows for some intricate puzzles and level design. Eversion's difficulty starts out quite low but rapidly accelerates into a challenging game as your progress.

The game does suffer from a couple of minor flaws. It's short - 7 levels short. However, there is a time attack mode with online highscores (with alternate versions of a couple levels), which gives the game a bit more replay value. There are also a couple areas where the hitboxes on the player make it difficult to maneuver through one-block gaps, but this only happens in a couple of areas.

9346381.review:
"The horror!"

A cheap little platformer, this might be one of the smallest games on Steam. I imagine anyone buying it just wanted it because it was cheap and looked cute. 

How wrong you are.  

Story
Something about the princess being taken is written on the store page. You won't really see much story once in the game, except for the ending. 

Presentation
Cute graphics here, they are what drew me in to purchasing this game. Little did I know that would soon change to a nightmarish landscape rather quickly. While they are rather basic and obviously inspired by classic games, they still look nice.

The isn't a lot of music in the game, but it fits the setting. Simple sound effects that do the job as well. Not really much to say about them. 

Controls
As the controls are rather simple, they work well on keyboard, but gamepads also have support if you prefer those. Movement, jumping, the Eversion ability (which shall be detailed below) and a pause button. You could play this with a NES clone controller if you own one. 

Gameplay
Run, jump, bounce off enemy heads, collect the gems and reach the end of the level.  Sounds like any NES era platformer game, right? Well, since the game opens up with a Lovecraft quote, there is obviously going to be something creepy lurking in the shadows. And that is where the Eversion ability comes in. In each level, there are locations where the walls between realities are weak. If you can find them, you can shift to another reality, often darker than the one you were already in. This will have an effect on both the landscape and enemies. That bush will wither and die, only to be replaced by deadly vines. Enemies may lose the will to live, just standing there for you to end its life, or it may get faster and more dangerous. Switching realities is needed to get all the gems through the levels, and sometimes even to progress forward through what would otherwise block movement. 

Lifespan
This game is short. Including the final level which requires you to find all the gems, you are unlikely to spend more than an hour or two doing the main game, including the different endings. Once you have seen the true ending, you do unlock a time attack mode with leader boards, which can add to the time spent on the game. There is also a level editor available, though I haven't played around with any of the community content myself. 

While not a bad game, the short game length alone is a good enough reason to only get on sale or with a Steam discount coupon.

6 / 10

For me, this game is like a hommage to, yet a parody of the Super Mario Bros series. The theme of 'a hero beats numerous monsters and finally saved his heroine' is embodied in this game. 9282921.review:
Turns out this one's quite an interesting little platformer, despite my initial impression being "yet another simplistic mario clone". 
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=129906696

The layer-changing mechanics are a nice touch -- at certain points in the levels the world can be "shifted" to a different layer which changes the behaviour of many level elements and enemies. Using this skill is necessary to beat the different stages, and abusing it is the only way to actually gather all the hidden gems. Makes for some interesting puzzles, though there is a fair amount of running back and forth. Also as the layers shift there is a visible degradation in the overall mood - starting at happy-go-lucky with layer one and ending at disturbed and insane. Naturally, the BGM changes along with the layers, and the different variations do reflect the mood of each layer nicely. 

The game's short so there's not much I can say about the "story" without spoiling the fun, though here's a nice little something to pique your interest (potential spoiler) -- Braid references (and not the insignificant kind)! This really made me smile and nod in approval.

Of downsides I found only one that bugged me -- poor controller support. My x360 controller was not recognised at all, had to plug in my old usb gamepad. And even then the ESC key (back to menu) cannot be mapped to the pad via in-game settings.

Overall, short (1-2 hours), fun, and a wee bit challenging to clear everything.

9277086.review:
Zaratustra does it with the fantastic platformer Eversion. 

[b]Story:[/b]
You play as Zee Tee a little cloud like creature that embarks on a mission to save a princess who was taken by Ghulibas. Sound familiar, well it should it’s essentially Mario. Unlike Mario where the levels, albeit fun, offer little in the realm of puzzling the game Eversion does. Eversion allows you to drift between realms by hitting eversion points where you can essentially shift the environment. This changes your impact on the world around you. And the enemies the world presents.

[b]The Ambience:[/b]
This is by no means a children’s game despite the colorful allure the steam snap shots show. For More Information read the following sentence, beware some would say this is a spoiler – [spoiler] The game presents a rather dismal idea about how bleak the world can really be. Entering emersions converts the game slowly to a more depressing state until the point of complete madness. [/spoiler] 

[b]Results:[/b]
Eversion is a game everyone should experience and enjoy. I highly recommend this game, although only if you can get it on sale for 75% or more off. I personally 100% completed this game, but if you just play through the game without doing 100% you can beat the game in less than thirty minutes. In my opinion 30 minutes is not worth $4.99. 

Pros:
+Fun atmosphere and great level design
+Levels have puzzles within them or require you to solve puzzles to proceed
+Great character control
+Interesting enemies
+Ability to change the levels based on the eversion you are in
+Multiple Endings
+Not as easy as it looks, but not too difficult
+Secret level
+Fun music

Cons:
-Really short game
-Game got corrupted after completing the map editing achievement and had to wipe my save (lucky the games only an hour long)
-Achievements are not all listed so you don’t know exactly what to do
-Full screen is not actually 1080p, causing windows on my other monitor to shift to the right of the screen.  (You can just leave the game in window mode and resize it)
-Default controls are rather odd, remember to click space bar in order to select the menu options (or change your controls like I did)

Eversion is a platforming, stress inducing, hair pulling, pain but still addicting and fun to play. No matter how much it will drive you nuts you’ll keep going just to not let it beat you. 

You play as a flower looking character in a 2D side-scroller like Super Mario Bros from the old school days. Hit once you die but it doesn’t really matter since you have unlimited lives and checkpoints through each level to help you along. While going through each level you are trying to collect a certain amount of jewels that will help you discover a secret in the end.

Controls are pretty fluid and easy since you only move side to side and jump. There’s also a little gameplay element called evert which will change up the level design when done. This is needed to find every jewel you need and to get to the end of the levels. Doing this will also sometimes add more of a challenge as the environment seems to become more violent.

Eversion can be beaten in say an hour or less depending on your platforming skills and frustration levels. I spent 3 hours in the game just to find every jewel and try to complete the secret stage which I couldn’t beat. It’s a well-made game and a great challenge for anyone that may be up for it especially at the low price of $5 and can be found at a lot less then that during sales.

Bear Rating: 10/10

A peine gagné et reçu, déjà terminé :'(. Moi qui pensais avoir à faire à un platformer 2D "difficile", il est au final extrêmement simple, mais reste bien plaisant. La mécanique de base étant de pouvoir "switch" de dimension à certains endroits. Il y a en tout 8 dimensions différentes mais toutes ne sont pas disponibles dans chaque niveau. Le but du jeu, outre finir les 8 mondes (j'ai fait les 7 standards conduisant à la fin en 40 minutes), est aussi de récolter toutes les gemmes du jeu (j'ai dû rajouter 20/30 minutes). Le monde 7 pour ces gemmes est le meilleur et le plus long puisque vous allez devoir traverser les 7 dimensions et 2 fois. Dans un ordre puis dans l'ordre en n'oubliant pas les actions à réaliser sans quoi l'accès à une ou plusieurs gemmes ne sera pas ou plus possible.

Reste encore 2 fins alternatives à voir, et il est aussi possible de récupérer les lettres du jeu qui sont apparemment cachées dans chaque niveau. Mais par "cachées" il faut comprendre invisibles et récupérables uniquement en étant à un endroit précis (en sautant ou autre). Si vous êtes patient, hf pour rechercher ça. Sinon il y a un guide bien foutu sur Steam entre autres. Je m'en suis servi pour finir le jeu à 100% (en ~2h).
Quand vous finissez le jeu avec la bonne fin, vous débloquez le mode "Time Attack", vous permattant de vous mesurer à vos amis et/ou à la communauté présente sur Steam. J'y ai aussi un peu joué mais mes scores ne sont pas glorieux :(. Juste une 13ème place sur le monde 3.

Bref, sympa, mais pas vraiment dur et ultra court. En même temps il était gratuit ce jeu à la base, puis ils ont fait cette version "HD" en vente sur Steam pour 4€ avec quelques ajouts.

Отличная игра платформер на первый взгляд клон Марио, но тут есть пару фич. Играем мы за милого цветочка Zee Tee, цель которого спасти принцессу Nehema (привет Марио). Главная фишка игры так сказать в изменении миров( "выворачивании"), в определенных местах вы можете изменить мир, меняется визуальный ряд, музыка и некоторые свойства, где-то монстры побыстрее, где-то можно бегать по облакам. 8557666.review:
Eversion is a platformer that takes cues from some older, more recognised platformers — like Mario. It looks like a cute little retro game, where you play a small flower-like creature out to rescue a princess. You collect gems, stomp enemies, and reach the flag. However, in reality, it’s ”cute” and familiar only to deceive the player.

One unique feature — and the main idea of this game — is “eversion”. In specific, small, invisible “hotspots” in the game (that you can reach) you can switch to another sort-of parallel reality, where some rules might be different. For example, clouds can be walked on in some realities, and in others, shrubs become trees that block your path.

The game’s called “Eversion” for a reason: as you progress through the game, it starts “turning inside out”, revealing the hell inside this beautiful, peaceful world. You start off in a cute dreamy land, collecting gems and passing by (or stomping) happy, innocent “enemies” that skip around. Soon enough, these enemies turn worse and your surroundings change. At some point, the game even starts lying to the player and occasionally tries to discourage the player from continuing, while at the same time breaking the fourth wall.

Eversion is rather short (less than an hour, possibly more to max it out), but it’s a great experience that anyone should play. It challenges game design standards and does a lot of things completely different compared to standard games, even indie ones.

Eversion might not be the most beautiful game or even the most innovative one , but it's still a very nice experience. The whole gameplay relies on a layers gimmick. You switch between them to navigate through obstacles, collect the diamonds and reach the goal. The further the layer, the weirder the surroundings and the harder the challenge. 

Although the gameplay is very fun, it's the mood that is set by each of the layers that really captures one's attention. You go from a poppy bright cheerful world into a twisted dark one. What should be pointed out is that the music plays a big role in maintaining the right feel for each of the dimensions. When it comes to the ending (well all 3 of them), it's the cherry on top of the cake.

All in all, I recommend this game to everyone who likes platformers, indie games or puzzle games but remember to keep in mind that the game lasts only for about 2 hours before you have everything unlocked. It's quite a shame because Eversion has potential to be much better than it already is.

[b]7/10[/b]

2D side scrolling platformer. You jump on enemies, collect gems and try to reach a flag at the end of each level. The hero doesn't have any special powers, and there's no power-ups to be collected either. The world is colorful, bright and playfully decorated. Sounds like a real drag, eh?

Now here's the twist: by visiting certain places in each level, you make the world everse into darker and more hellish dimensions so that you can reach that famous flag at the end. Enemies gets quicker and more sinister, devil hands try to reach out from the pits to grab you, the colors shift to desolate, icy, bleak and the bushes and flowers wither and die. Oh, and there's a fog from hell chasing you, wanting to consume all in it's path.

What makes the game great is the aestethic, and the replay value added in the achievements. It's a pretty short game, but as a piece of art it's well worth it's money. I'd buy it again.

8/10, as far as artsy, weird platformers go.

7887471.review:
Eversion is not what you think. The unassuming and colorful visuals are intended not to delight, but to give you a false sense of security; to draw you in before transporting you to the nightmarish world of its reality. It's intentionally unsettling, and unique in how it manages to get under your skin while never assuming anything is wrong, which is what I find so remarkable about it.

The hook to Eversion is everting the world, similar to swapping dimensions, which causes the environment to change properties or even disappear. It's a simple mechanic that allows for some clever lever designs, but it is also where the game becomes very, very creepy. The deeper you go through the layers of everting, the more twisted the backgrounds become and the more deranged the music gets. The disclaimer at the start should tell you all you need to know: "this game is not suitable for children or those with a nervous demeanor."

Although it lacks the nuance of something like Braid, Eversion similarly uses video game cliches as the foundation of the experience, relying on your expectations to carry the premise as it warps the familiar into something all its own. In this developer Zaratustra Productions is mostly successful, with my only complaint being I wish there was more here. With the exception of a few odd secrets, you can complete and collect everything in around two hours (those disinclined to gather all the gems should expect half or less than that). Even with its low base price, it feels a little too much for what you get.

Aside from the price, Eversion is something I think is worth your time. It completely surprised me in its execution, leaving me chilled and a little disturbed, but impressed nonetheless. If you are looking for something off the beaten path, Eversion is one game that will absolutely deliver. It doesn't last long, but this strange journey is undoubtedly one worth taking, provided you are prepared for the potentially terrifying.

[b]You can read more of my writing on [url=http://kritiqal.com/2013/12/02/eversion-review/]Kritiqal[/url].[/b]

Eversion is a simple sidescrolling game in the vein of Super Mario Brothers. The game is cheery in its initial playing, but gives into a darker asthetic. 

The game has no powerups, but the game feautures a mechanic where the player can evert to different forms of a level. Collectible gems may be out of reach in one form, but attainable in another. Over the course of 8 levels and attaining all the gems, a final level is unlocked.

The music is cheery when the level is cheery, the music is somber when the level is somber, and the music is dreadful when the level is dreadful. This goes for enemies as well and death animations of the enemies.

4761082.review:
Eversion is one of those great things in a small package, bringing back the glory days of classic Mario while adding some gameplay twists and a simple but entertaining plot that makes this a cute horror platformer well worth playing.

The game is essentially a flash platformer with the old console/gameboy feel. You have enemies and an end of a level to reach, but in order to do so you must overcome obstacles. This could be a plant in your way or objects that need to be made solid. You do this by finding the Eversion, a dimensional changing point that warps everything on the level. That plant will become a weed that you can walk through, etc. Finding the correct order and where they're located is the main challenge of the game. But the deeper into the Eversions you go, the harder enemies become and the more environmental challenges you must face. It's quite fun!

The game can be completely beaten with 100% achievements in a couple of hours. That includes bonus levels. While it was originally freeware (that version is still available I think) and bundled, I don't think that devalues this game in the slightest. The game also supports a level editor which has to be downloaded separately.

In summary, it's a short, simple, fun game that has a charming presentation and solid gameplay mechanics. Anyone that liked Mario will find plenty to enjoy here. It also has cards now! What are you waiting for? :)

4802282.review:
Eversion is a different sort of game. Despite looking like the bright, cheery platform games of old, this game is a puzzle game with some platform elements. This game features 240 gems, or "Glitters", scattered around the game's 8 levels. The game boasts the amazing ability to "evert", or warp between different versions of a level. Each of the worlds use vivid colors, so the game is not overly dark, meaning it could be played well at night. The game boasts a lovely chiptune soundtrack that's best shared alone (why let mere mortals listen to its greatness?). As for playing with friends, Eversion also has a great time attack mode that adds a lot of replay ability. On top of that, there's hidden items to collect in each level, making this a game you'll play a lot, whether you want to or not. Eversion is a wonderfully happy game everyone* should play.

*Not intended for children or those of a nervous disposition.

3722463.review: Eversion is a nice little platformer with a thought-provoking dark twist. The "eversion" skill allows players to change the mechanics of various world features (clouds, blocks, enemies, etc.) and adds an understated but brilliant puzzle element to the game's relatively small number of stages. It's short, but it's great quality for the price.

673498.review:
I really really like eversion. It just seemed such an innocuous and cute little platformer in the beginning that reminded me of Mario on LSD with the bright and colourful atmosphere. Deceivingly easy too. However, that quickly changed as I progressed through the levels which got surprisingly harder with every new layer of dimension being added to my game. Not only does the theme change to a more darker and threatening ambience, but it also modifies the environment and the difficulty with it. Clouds materialise then disappear, enemies become slower, then faster, and even your innocent little flower from layer 1 will soon become a thorny bush that will make you blow up by touching it.

I found the themes to be really creepy. I think that is what made the biggest impression on me, the music that gradually became more chaotic, the darker colour palettes, the vast amounts of hemoglobin, the hands, etc... Level 6 just gets your adrenaline going, though after the 10th death you kinda start getting used to it. I'm not that good at platformers, yet I wanted to 100% this one. So it did take me a couple hours to get everything, and it was indeed a nice challenge without being SMB-"suicidal", as Monukai (http://steamcommunity.com/id/Monukai/recommended/33680/) put it.

The only thing I'd criticise this game for would be its short length (that's what she said). Also, I felt that the first few dimensions were a bit underrepresented in the later levels. Basically what I'm saying is, eversion certainly has a LOT of potential. I could imagine trickier and more complex levels being made with a bit of creativity which I unfortunately don't have.

Anyhow, I fully endorse the thought that eversion is well worth the few quid (though mine was a bundle buy #cheapskate). I wouldn't mind seeing a sequel of this 'cute' little gem, so please, anyone?

基本的にマリオ。

ステージ上に隠された特定のエリア（エリアに入ると音楽が少し変わる）でボタンを押すと環境が変わり、
ブロックが壊せるようになったり、雲の上に乗れるようになったりする。

3708718.review: Eversion is a delightful romp through a colorful platformer! In it, you play a little flower guy named "Zee Tee", on a quest to find the princess. Using Zee Tee's "evert" technique, you can change the world, making clouds into solid platforms or allowing shrubs to be passed by. You'll need to make good use of it if you want to find your princess, but you'll need to make expert use of it if you want to find all the gems and win her heart! Although a little short, the game does include a time trial mode and at least one reason to re-explore the levels, in the form of a tip of the hat to Braid. At $5 for a few hours of quality content, I feel it's worth it. At $2.50 during a sale, I'd say you're doing yourself a disservice by not giving it a shot.

普天同庆 Steam 第三方游戏 Eversion 的成就汉化成功。这是里程碑事件，在此之前鲜有 Steam 第三方游戏的成就能得到汉化。

2012-01-10
这次圣诞Steam没出小游戏包，所以没买多少游戏，而且又怕各种小游戏进各种外部的慈善包，因此现在对购入小游戏得尤为谨慎，但是根据我对开发商的分析，觉得这个游戏目前进入各种包的可能性不大，所以还是花1.25美元给买了。
之前就知道这游戏猎奇又难玩的很，没想到真的是猎奇又难玩的很。
游戏部分抄袭（就是山寨）超级马里奥，部分原创。不过这游戏在复古2D风格游戏里，个人并不怎么喜欢，反正有人是喜欢的，因为这游戏的谜题设计的有够狠的。背景音乐太过猎奇，某些节点难度设置过高（甚至超过VVVVVV），好在一共8关不那么累人，不过游戏设置了3种结局，一般人不大容易找全。
最后一个成就非常值得吐槽，就是要求不得篡改游戏文件——你这是要展示你这游戏的反篡改侦测能力么？结果一开始改了一个文本文档，根本没检测出来，第二次把地图删了一个，才检测出来。
个人对此游戏的评价低于Braid。

572983.review:
It's like Mario, if Mario was loosing his mind.

But seriously, it's really good. The core "eversion" concept is pretty awesome, changing everything about a level every time you go up or down a "layer." The top layer is super happy, but as you trudge deeper and deeper things get...less so. It isn't just about the visual or music changes, however; gameplay itself changes, with enemy AI changing routines, background elements changing their solidity, and some objects will turn from benign to deadly depending on what layer you're in. It all leads to some very fun and interesting puzzles. I highly reccomend Eversion to anyone interested in a great platformer/puzzler/experimental experience.

4238078.review:
You know when a game quotes Lovecraft on the intro screen that something eerie is in store for you and you get that and a tad more when you play this game for any length of time.
 
The gameplay mechanics dealing with the platforming and puzzle elements of having to deal with ‘changing’ the environment so that its properties shift and you are able to continue your progress collecting gems or just finishing the level are sound and entertaining but the game itself is all about its presentation and the theme of the deceptive facade that hides the many underneath.

The clever puzzle solving utilizing the evert technique is enjoyable and the payoff of the different endings worth the time and effort to see through this game through the end. The music is wonderful and truly does a good job of portraying the current state of the gameworld.

It’s a peculiarly eerie and memorable trip to rescue a princess in dire need of your help. If you enjoy the base gameplay you won’t regret undertaking it.

4260912.review:
What initially seems like a colorful Mario NES clone turns out to be a bit more.  In Eversion you find access points throughout the levels where you can evert, altering the entire state of the level (seasons, if you will).  Each version of the level has its own unique properties and you may need to shift many times to find secrets, get to all the gems, overcome obstacles or complete the level.  While it's nowhere near anything like Braid, it can make you think but is mostly common sense and trial and error.  You won't get frustrated or have to strain your brain much. 

Multiple endings, achievements and plays great with a gamepad.  The game is only a couple hours long but it was fun enough for me to finish in one sitting.

Okay, so unless I haven't done anything wrong, the game is pretty short (took me about 20mins), but the idea behind it is quite creative with the "layer shiftings". It starts out cute and happy, but gets darker and more nightmare-like as you go. 

The platform style reminds a lot of Super Mario; the overall look of games like Bubble Bobble and co. 
You can't turn the sound down, or at least I didn't see an option, but you CAN use a controller, which makes it way nicer to play, IMO. 

If anybody is looking for a kind of bizarre, but short, simple; yet interesting little platformer that keeps you busy for a litte or as a thing to set the mood for Halloween even, then go for it. 
As the store page says, 8 worlds (aka levels). If you want to make the game last longer, you can (or almost should) also just try to get all the achievements and / or the other 2 alternative endings (there are 3 in total). Cool game. =3

811254.review:
Looks like a short game, with only 5 'worlds' or so (few minutes each). It's a nice platformer, bit hard though. It's very precise, and not in a good way. There are sometimes jumps that are impossible to pull off with a keyboard which makes it a frustrating experience. It has a cool feature that lets you switch between universes, though. It's part of the gameplay and not just a gimmick.

Apparently the story is quite deep for a platformer. But since I haven't been able to finish it just yet I can't tell you if that's really the case or not (in fact, I can't really say that I've seen a story at all so far in). 

The graphics are simple and remind me of a Gameboy Color game. As well as the sounds. 
Now comes the question. Would I recommend it ? Yes. Yes, I would. The price is worth it and despite the frustrations I do think there's a deeper story hidden somewhere.

[Rating: 72/100]

This is a game that will get inside your head and lay venomous eggs. It starts in a SMB-meets-Kirby primary colored fun world that makes you think back to the days when you would get grham crackers and juice from your mom after you come downstaris from playing video games. 

Then, it gets dark.  

The music becomes a distorted 16-bit funeral hymn just slightly reminiscient of the bright, shiney tunes you had just been platforming to not a minute ago. The world around you decays and the monsters transform from harmless lumps of cute you can't hardly stand to jump on for the handful of points to cyclopsian balls of coagulated blood that must eat your flesh and dreams to sustain themselves. 

Honestly, the gameplay mechanics barely even matter (but are definitely good fun) with a game this damn atmospheric. After I reached the "Confusion" layer of Lovecraftian horror and found myself thinking "I want to go back to a world where good things happen." 

Play this game. Now.

2406436.review:
Super Mario Bros. and a pleasurable discomfort as you work deeper into the world.
----- ----- ----- ----- ----- ----- ----- ----- ----- ----- ----- ----- ----- ----- ----- ----- -----
SOUNDS - POSSIBLY MUSICAL - HEARD IN THE NIGHT FROM OTHER WORLDS OR REALMS OF BEING.

 Eversion is a platformer in the vein of Super Mario Bros. (to the point that the game files call the enemies "goombas", and an achievement makes reference to the first SMB). On the subject of Achievements, those, leaderboards for a "time attack" mode, and graphical improvements are what you're actually paying for in this Steam release; the developer, Zaratustra Productions, also has a freeware version available at their site, zarat.us/tra.

 According to the manual (available from the game's Steam Store page), you are Zee Tee, a brave -a-s-t-e-r-i-s-k- warrior, out to save the Flower Kingdom's Princess -N-e-h-e-m-a-, -k-i-d-n-a-p-p-e-d- by the Ghuliba forces of the north. Aside from that, there's not much explicit story to be had. However, as per the game's title, there are many layers to this quaint little story, just as there are layers to the world itself. Along with the jumping around, jumping on enemies, jumping to headbutt blocks established with SMB and its kin, the eversion mechanic allows you to evert at certain places on the stages, changing how the stage behaves. The physics will always stay the same, but stage elements and enemies will shift with the peeling layers of reality.

 And you'll need to evert, too, to get everything there is. There are 240 gems to collect, and nabbing all these buggers will push your reflexes and understanding of the game's mechanics to get yourself to where they are. There tend to be at least a couple ways to accomplish these feats, though, which opens it up a bit for experimentation.

 I definitely like the graphics boost this version has over the freeware. The added detail really brings out what you're seeing, and keeps it from becoming "just a bunch of sprite tiles". The only sacrifice is one if you prefer simplicity, especially during the endings (oh, yes, there's more than one ending to find), but I don't think the little flourishes diminish the effect the game gives. The music helps with the effect, though it may get on your nerves if you end up in a stage too long. However, until that point, they're pretty catchy, with a technical level that matches the retro aesthetic the game's made with. And both will help you find the eversion points, as these nexuses will blend the sounds and colors of the layers they lead to.

 As for the challenge, I think you'd have to know if you're compatible with platformers to play this one. If you're cool with the run-&-jump, you should be able to get through to an ending with enough effort, though to truly delve into everything, you may end up offput, but not enough to drive you away from the game permanently. The levels, aside from the first, have checkpoints midway through the stage, though if you quit the stage, you'll have to begin from the top. Some stages require precise jumping (with one calling for vertical block-scaling, jumping from one block to one directly above it) or races against time, and compiled with the other stage dangers, you can end up falling to your quick death many times (each time resetting the music, to boot). The game's not too terribly long, though, at less than ten stages (with a couple as part of the Time Attack mode), so if you're especially good at platformers, you may end up breezing through. And for any skill level, have some solace that your gems (and hidden 'items'; one per stage) are saved as soon as you grab them, so if you die, you don't lose your loot.

 Despite how much time you get out of it, at five dollars, it's not a bank-buster, and I like what the game does to recommend it to anyone willing, whether they go with the freeware or Steam release (though if you're letting a friend play on your account, you may want to move your .sav file somewhere else and let them have a fresh start). It won't warp your brain, but it can make you uncomfortable/insecure in the game's world, and for whatever frustrations it gives, I did have a smile on when calling out on the game's ridiculous "bullcrap" moments.

 Just, just keep in mind: this is "not suitable for children or those of a nervous disposition." *wink*

 NOTE: My Steam profile reads me as having 11 hours on this game, but some amount of that time was just goofing around or showing it to my folks (because, really, it's that neat).
